description.text:
This is a Tiny Whoop gate that meets the multigp regulation.

It's a heptagon (7 sides polygon) made of 3-D printed joiners and Bamboo skewers. The bamboo skewers need the tip cut off and are bout 10" long.

Best results are to have the skewers glued in. Hot glue maybe best.

Alignment of skewers when gluing the whole gate together is critical.

To sit on the ground place a weight on the bottom crossbar. In my case I've used a very large washer (it is covered by the paper chevron in the second picture).

The skewers are hard to see in the FPV camer even when painted red. One could use fluorescent tape or attached leds.

I've provided a PDF of a chevron. Print, fold and glue. Again hot glue gun might be better as it has quicker set up time. The bottom of the gate is the same chevron print unfolded and glued to another plain sheet.

Cutting the skewer shorter will make a smaller gate.

title: CR-10 Filament RunOut Switch Mount for TH3D's EZOUT

description.text: This is a very simple platform mount for the EZOUT filament runout switch made by Tim Hoogland (TH3DStudio.com). I use it on my CR-10 S5 (500x500) but i guess it could be used with other sensors also. It's just a platform. ha. Anyway, I wanted the switch to be mounted somehow instead of it just dangling on the filament. You'll need a M5x40 (or maybe M5x45 and cut it back, like i did with my dremel tool) to replace the M5 bolt that holds the V-Slot wheel in place. At the time of posting this I'm obviously holding the EZOUT to the mount with a rubber band but double sided tape or manually drilling holes to add zip ties is possible too. Not sure drilling holes are needed though.

description.text:
Workhorse Printer is an open source 3d printer released by 3D Distributed in 2017. The project is still a work in progress. If you have any questions or suggestions contact [email protected] If you need a modification or custom model contact us. If you want to bring your own printer to market using our components contact us. The machine is open source non-commercial but we can make proper arrangements or license deal if needed. Just consult with us first.

www.3ddistributed.com

Igus Lead Screw on XY Axis

We used Igus high helix lead screw on the x and y axis for speed

This is a set of chess pieces I designed that has a customized holder for the pieces.
They are scaled to fit on a board with square sizes around 1.5 inches. They can be easily scaled down but they have some fine details that look and print better at original size or larger, especially the Knight.

Supports can be a pain to remove from the pieces but are necessary for some.

Each of the parts were designed in SolidWorks, mostly using revolves. The Knight was designed using a lot of surfaces and more complex functions.
The part that holds all of the pieces was made by aligning the pieces on a box in an assembly and then taking a cavity of the pieces slightly up-scaled. It was originally designed to fit into a chess board box so has extra pillars.

These are my own version of Catan Pieces.

They are to the sizes I measured from my wood pieces.

They print great.

Also the ones in the picture are at 50% scale from my slicer so one can make a mini-Catan set.
To get 50% just scale in half from the slicer.
50% scaled pieces fit in this my half sized box: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2764091

Files attatched are full size and should fit my own Catan storage box (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2471282)

description.text:
This is a small tool to assist you in cutting a bevel in foam board as they do at flite test. This will guarantee that you get a clean and accurate bevel without it looking wavy or cutting through the paper. It uses standard utility knife style blades (the trapezoid looking ones).

Youtube video of it in action...

https://youtu.be/GWqAG0Q9zAw

Prusa

i3 MK2S

No

No

Resolution:

.2mm layer height

Infill:

15%

Notes:

prints easy with the pegs oriented up. There was a little drooping by the slot as it printed, but it did not affect performance.

How to use:

Use pliars (please) to push the razor blade into the housing. It goes in at an angle to utilize more of the blade surface, the bevel is 45 degrees. Then place over the foam board that has been folded back onto itself (just like the flite test videos) and run it through the device. The discarded foam will come out of the top.

remixed_from.author: TexasLaser
remixed_from.title: Gear Clock.  New design style. Minute face is the whole cutout of hour wheel gear.  Minute hand is traditional type for easier reading. Stencil cut.

description.text:
I thought TexasLaser's gear clock was the most clever use of the space, but by not embedding the fonts, no one could print it. So I made a new one with more computery fonts for myself. The original file also had nearly 8 types of cuts in it, which I just did not understand, so I reduced it down to black for engraving parts, red for cuts. If I made a mistake, I hope someone will tell me, I've not done much laser cutting yet.

There are numerous small gears for, I assume, different types of clock motions. Choose the one that will work for you, stack two of them and glue them to the minute hand and toss the rest.

comments.text: Nice piece of work!

title: DIY | Anycubic kossel filament runout sensor on marlin 1.1.8

description.text:
Voici comment installer sous marlin 1.1.8 un détecteur de filament biqu (le support est fait pour, après a vous de l'adapter pour un autre modèle ;) , le reste sera tous de mème valide) sur une Anycubic linear plus (ou autre modèle avec une trigorilla).

https://github.com/GolDNenex/Marlin_AnycubicKosselPlus

All is translated by google translation, if you had a better trad a comment allows you to tell me ;).

Here is how to install under marlin 1.1.8 a filament detector biqu (the support is made for, after a you will adapt it for another model;), the rest will all be valid) on an Anycubic linear plus (or other model with a trigorilla).

Materiels :

(1) - 2x Tnut pour/for 2020 extrusion
(2) - 2x M4x12
(3) - 2x M3x25
(4) - 1x support_detecteur_filamentBiqu.stl / a vous de voir comment vous l'imprimer
(5) - 1x cache_detecteur_v1.stl / it's up to you to see how you print it
(6) - 1x détecteur de filament biqu (https://www.amazon.fr/gp/product/B0748C4CS5/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o00_s00?tag=li3d-21) ou autre détecteur mais a vous de vérifier que le connecteur est compatible/or other detector but you have to check that the connector is compatible..

Installation :

Étapes:

1- Après avoir installer et vérifier la position du support, brancher un coter du câble fournit sur le détecteur et l'autre sur le Servo0 (Pin 11 photo en dessous). A vous de voir pour le câble-management, moi le support a bobine est derrière donc le câble passe dans cette direction entre les barres du bas avec le câble de l'extrudeur.

2- Lancer Marlin ( Télécharger si vous n'avais pas https://www.arduino.cc/ et http://marlinfw.org/).

3- Dans le fichier Configuration.h
Dé-commenter la ligne '' #define ADVANCED_PAUSE_FEATURE'' (CTRL+F au besoin), plusieurs fonction telle que "#define PARK_HEAD_ON_PAUSE " seront a activer.

4- Maintenant que la fonction M600 est activé, dans le fichier Configuration.h
Dé-commenter la ligne "#define FILAMENT_RUNOUT_SENSOR" et régler au besoin FIL_RUNOUT_INVERTING sur false (ou true suivant le fonctionnement de votre détecteur mais si vous avais celui du tutoriel c'est bien false)

5- Dans le fichier Pins_ramps.h:
Chercher et Dé-commenter et/ou régler "FIL_RUNOUT_PIN" sur le PIN 11.

Vous avais maintenant un détecteur de filament fonctionnel. J'espere que ce tutoriel vous sera utile ;)

Nenex

Installation :

Steps:

1- After having installed and checking the position of the support, connect a dimension of the cable provided with on the detector and the other on the Servo0 (Pin 11 photo above). For you to see for the cable-management, I support the coil is behind so the cable passes in this direction between the bottom bars with the cable of the extruder.

2- Launch Marlin (Download if you did not https://www.arduino.cc/ and http://marlinfw.org/).

3- In the Configuration.h file
De-comment the line '' #define ADVANCED_PAUSE_FEATURE '' (CTRL + F as needed), several functions such as "#define PARK_HEAD_ON_PAUSE" will be activated.

4- Now that the M600 function is enabled, in the Configuration.h file
De-comment the line "#define FILAMENT_RUNOUT_SENSOR" and adjust if necessary FIL_RUNOUT_INVERTING on false (or true according to the operation of your detector but if you had that of the tutorial it is indeed false)

5- In the Pins_ramps.h file:
Search and De-comment and / or set "FIL_RUNOUT_PIN" on PIN 11.

You now had a functional filament detector. I hope this tutorial will be useful to you;)

This is a project box sized to fit a doTERRA diffuser power circuit in.

Unfortunately we had a dud power pack shortly out of factory (which was quickly and easily replaced by doTERRA). Not wanting to waste it, I opened up to investigate and discovered that one of the mains connectors was faulty.

After attempting just to solder directly onto the broken pin I went about creating a replacement power brick from an existing project box on Thingiverse (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2477714 thanks cudatox) and modified it in TinkerCAD for cables and logo.

Also gives added bonus of slightly longer cable length for the sometimes awkward distances (which we had one of).

Printer:

Cocoon Create

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

20%

Post-print

After printing I did minimal clean-up of the print.

I did however have to cut/grind small notes in the lid of the box to accommodate the AC and device cables to fit through nicely without straining the box. Just a 1mm or two rectangular cut-out for the diffuser and shallow oval on the AC end. If I have to make another one I will likely update the model to include this.

Parts and Disassembly/Assembly

You will need to source a power cord to feed into the power brick. Mine was an old kettle base, which also included a cable clamp (very important people). If your donor cord doesn't have something please ensure you secure the AC cord in some way with clamps, cable ties or remix to include built in.

To open the existing power pack I ran a dremmel cutting wheel all around. There is enough clearance inside to do this safely.

To separate the circuit board from the case you will need to use needle-nose pliers to pinch the AC pin clips and free the metal connectors from the AC pins of the case to the circuit board. I only had to do one side do to the fault :)

After than desolder the metal AC connectors from the circuit board, very easy with solder-wick/sucker and ben the clip out. I ended up drilling out the existing holes on the circuit board slightly to accommodate the new AC wires but you may not need to do this.

Then I hot-glued the circuit board and the clamp in place, feed the cables in the guide holes and place the lid on to confirm all fits (and powers on). I hot glued the lid in place after this but I'd recommend simply supergluing as in theory the box will never have to be opened again!

Dismantled my donor cable and doTERRA power pack to look at what parts I had available. Then sketched out minimum sizes to search for existing boxes so I did not have to reinvent the wheels.

Original though was to have screw pegs (as donor had extra screws) but figured I won't be opening this up very often so forwent that idea.

In the very small chance I have to create another power-brick I will likely shrink the box slightly as there is still some room around and make all the parts self-contained, with built in cable clamp and maybe clip on lid.

Part size restrictions (top) and box overview (below) including original peg idea. The box lid has in this design doTERRA stamped in it. I designed as it was my first 'custom' design that I would go all out and put my partner's name on it :)

I would love to see someone print this out with a multi-material printer. Could produce incredible results.

comments.text: What? "Scale Model" how? It's a representation at best, it doesn't show atoms or anything.
comments.author: Denkiri

comments.text:
Yes, you're right that it's not a scale models of all of the atoms. It's a scale model to highlight the overall structure of DNA (while also being reasonably easy to 3D print), not the molecular structure. It's a scale model in the sense that the phosphate backbone is twisting at the proper angle and the base pairs are spaced at the correct relative distance. The scale is roughly 1:20,000,000.
Hope this helps explain my reasoning for it being a "Scale Model."
comments.author: Denkiri

comments.text: The other comment is correct, and I'm sorry to say it, but this is a left-handed helix.  DNA is right-handed.  Having said that... this is a cool concept!  Fix it and I will use it for teaching biology!  Love the idea.

This is a rubber band powered robot. It can be assembled and will jump way into the air when pressed down and released. My 7 year old daughter, Cecilia, is fascinated with cad designing and robotics. She has been begging me to design an original robot. I finally told her that if she drew up what she wanted the robot to look like, I would design it for her. So 5 minutes later she brought me a hand drawn picture of the robot she designed. I asked her what she would like her robot to accomplish and do. She very loudly said, "Jump, Jump, Jump!!! Really High!!!" Thus, this rubber band powered robot is dubbed "CeeBot", after my beautiful daughter. I have posted a picture of her lovely design. Please see build and print instructions for details.
This was designed in Fusion 360.

Build List and Assembly Instructions

You will need the following parts printed in the following quantities:

Hair Cap - 1 (Optional- Was designed as a removable cap for printability)
Upper Body - 1
Lower Body - 1
Lower Leg - 8
Upper Leg - 8
Leg Mounting Pin - 8(Optional - Can be assembled with pin of your choice)
Leg Pin - 8 (Optional - Can be assembled with pin of your choice)

Assembly Instructions:

Assembly the legs by insterting the disc section of the upper leg into the disc slot of the lower leg. Ensure that the rubber band hooks on the front of the legs are facing the same direction. There is a rubber band hook on the upper leg section near the disc. The one on the lower leg is neer the foot. Insert pin or screw of your choice through the hold in the discs(if using a screw, do not over tighten. the hinge must be able to move with little resistance). Instal rubber band into the top and bottom rubber band hooks.

Once the legs are assembled insert the top parts of the legs through the slots in the bottom of the Lower Body. Ensure that the open end of the rubber band slot at the top of the leg is facing the center of the robot. Align the hole in the upper leg portion with the saddle holes in the interior of the robot. Insert Leg Mounting Pins or pins or screws of your choice through the saddle and the upper leg holes.

Stretch rubber band(s) around the rubber band hooks on the interior of the lower body. Then stretch them over the top of the upper leg and place it in the rubber band slot of the upper leg.

Install the upper body by aligning the 3 grooves of inside the flange with the slots in the flange of the lower body. When the grooves are lower to the bottoms of the slots, turn right.

Press on the Hair Cap to the upper body section, and now you have your very own rubber band power jumping CeeBot!!!!!!

I have not built this yet. If there are any issues with the design or if you have any further questions about the design or assembly, please email me at [email protected] Thanks, and happy printing!!!!
This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/dJg8vmvC8zM

title: RC Car Motor Pinion Generator / Customizer. Mod1, 32p, 48p, with hole for M3 or M4 screw grub, D-shape or key MyRCCar compatible

description.text:
Hi there! I used Modulus Gear Customizer to create my pinion and had to add a hole for a screw grub in other program. After doing this i wanted to make some little modifications and i had to repeat the process. So I took a depth look to the customizer code and added some features to the existing one.

Now you can generate pinion gears for 3.175mm and 5mm motor shafts, with M3 or M4 hole for the screw grub if you want, with D-shaped center hole and also with key as you could in the remixed thing.

I already generated the Mod1 pinions from 10 to 23 teeth with the next common parameters:

  • Center hole: for 3.17mm shaft
  • Gear thickness: 7
  • Hub Extension: 7
  • Hub diameter: from 8 to 12mm
  • D-Shaped center hole: NO
  • Grub screw: M3
  • Grub screw extra height: 1mm
  • Presure Angle: 20
  • Keyway: NO

If you can't generate your desired pinion within the customizer, download openSCAD and edit the ModulusGear_dlbMod5.scad file to your likes.

Please if you give it a try for your RC Car tell me if it works good, in wich material you printed it and if it lasts. If you find an error please tell me asap too!!! :)

comments.text: Are these 32 pitch gears?
comments.author: sharkattack99

comments.text: The generated pinions are Mod1. This is not 32 pitch. You should be able to generate them or the one you want in the customizer, but it doesn't work for me from sometime ago. Instead you can download OpenSCAD and generate it there. You will also be able to tune the parameters more than in customizer.

description.text:
This item is intended to  solve a familiar problem for anyone who uses small bottles of paint, glue, or other volatile or messy liquids; i.e. to provide a solid support for these bottles so the danger of tipping when using a brush, toothpick, eyedropper, etc. is greatly decreased. These holders also have small vertical supports around the edge for small items.
Since the design is parametric it can easily be customized for pretty much any sized bottle that will fit your printer's bed. The design is optimized to use as little plastic as possible while still providing a solid support.

For those who use American sized bottles, three different .stl files are provided that match the 1/2, 1, and 2 ounce bottles used for Floquil and Testors paint and Plastruct cements. Of course these files should work for any similar or slightly smaller bottles. Diameters are as follows: 1/2 ounce size: ~32.5 mm
1 ounce size: ~36.5 mm
2 ounce size: ~41 mm A large oval flask holder stl file is also supplied. This was designed for an 8 ounce bottle about 45 x 65 mm, but might work for other oval bottles. If you need a different size you'll need to modify the OpenSCAD file by changing the relevant variables and exporting a new .SIL file. In most cases this is very simple, only the bottle diameter and height values normally would need changing for round bottles. The parameters allow for other variations: oval bottles can be accommodated, and the number and size of the small brush holders around the perimeter of the base can be altered. Details on the variables for these possibilities are in the .scad files.

One of the complaints about Mechen hands is that elastics or springs are used to extend fingers. When flexing, the user has to fight the resistance of these elastics or springs, reducing the strength of grip.
So here's a tentative solution. There's a rod that pushes a mechanism on a hinge during extension, and engages extension cables.
So instead of 5 cables and 5 elastics, this uses 10 cables. The flexor cables should be heavy-duty and have close to zero stretch, but the extensors could just be 60-pound nylon monofilament.
First test shown here: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hqd3zUXpZDA
Second test: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oUJIHFQu1jg&feature=youtu.be
For more information or to get involved, visit http://enablingthefuture.org/
Files updated March 31, 2014

There are two .stl files here. One will print with no support, and the other needs support to print well. (At least, with my Solidoodle) You need a couple small screws to put together the anchor mechanism.
This is made to fit the Talon Hand, but the anchor mechanism really needs to be adapted to the Cyborg Beast gauntlet.

title: MonoPrice Select Mini Bed Expansion V2 (150mmx230mm)

description.text:
This is a revision of YourDrunkle's design. I've updated the bed holders to work with thumb-wheels. I've also included two versions of the thumb-wheel. Print 4x of whichever you choose. Photos above and the summary below are pulled directly from Yourdrunkle's design.

This is a modification to expand the MonoPrice Select Mini's print bed depth to 230mm on the cheap. I am able to utilize a printable area of 130mm x 220mm with just these modifications. The price once built was approximately $60 for me. This is nearly the same price as the unheated version of the "4th dimension modifications" "Maximus" kit but my build includes a heated bed. Note that you will need to upgrade the Select Mini's power supply to utilize the heater but I hope to be making a basic guide for that as well soon.

Some notes about this project:

  • No special tools (except a 3D printer) are needed for this project. I used a hacksaw to cut the aluminum, scissors, a drill with 1/8" and 5/32" drill bits, and a measuring device.
  • Most of the non-3D printer specific parts (8mm rod, belt, and the bed itself) were purchased from my local Ace Hardware.
  • I used a lot of Imperial sized (6-32) bolts instead of Metric (M3 or M4) bolts. Im in the US, so they are WAY cheaper locally. Seriously, like 1/3 to 1/2 the price. Sorry, I'd rather use metric too... M4 will PROBABLY work fine and allow use of the nut inserts.

Links to what I used:
Print Bed:
https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B01AAYY70Y/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o01_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1
Belt (note: this is WAY too much belt. You only need ~30cm and could save money by buying a smaller quantity):
https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00F2IQNX8/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o00_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1
Rods:
https://www.ebay.com/itm/300-350-400mm-8mm-Chromed-Rod-Parts-DIY-CNC-Linear-Rail-Shaft-for-3D-Printer/122850462999?hash=item1c9a754d17:m:m3bE2vd9IhcoeTMEq0XmC7Q
Everything else was locally purchased at Ace Hardware.

A REALLY REALLY BRIEF BUILD GUIDE:
Looking at your printer as it comes apart is crucial. This "guide" is very broad and skips a lot of stuff that you should be able to figure out on your own.

  • Printing
    I printed everything with 100% infill and 0.1mm layers with PLA. Time will tell if the PLA holds up tot he heat from the print bed but I am confident. I am able to fit it all in 3 print files on the stock Select Mini. It took a long time but it is very rigid and looks good IMO.

  • Cutting Aluminum:
    Cut aluminum to 150mm for the front and rear and approximately 2-5mm shorter than your rods for the left and right sides. Its ok for the aluminum to be a few mm short but not a few mm long.

  • Drilling:
    Assemble and square the frame off of the printer. Ensure that the 8mm rods are against the aluminum and are the same spacing as on the printer. Use a 1/8" drill bit to drill through the holes in the 3D printer parts. Expand the holes shown in the pictures in the aluminum only. The expanded holes are to allow for some adjustability in the system.

  • Assembly:
    When the frame is initially assembled on the printer, do not tighten the 2 screws in the front and rear that were drilled oversized. Push the frame to the farthest back point of travel and tighten the front screw and vise versa. This prevent binding.

  • Installing the bed
    When installing the bed, I placed the connector for the electronics toward the outside of the printer. It will bind if placed on the inside.
  • Installing the belt:
    The belt loops through this frame differently than the stock printer. However, it still goes through the stepper motors the same way and the layout in the frame should be obvious. The ribs in the belt will sit in the ribs on the inside edge of the frame.

comments.text: I see one potential issue with this revision. The top of the bed holder is very thin and I think it would be pretty flimsy as drawn. description.text:
I wanted a webcam cover for my laptop but most of the covers on thingiverse seemed to be quick designs that lacked strength, consistency or were simply too hard to mount. So I built my own.

It's not radically different than many others but it does provide a nice assembly and smoother operation. Most importantly, because it has a back, it is very easy to stick enough double sided tape on it to make mounting easy without messing up the operation.

I tried to keep it as thin as possible (<1.2mm) so it should fit on most laptop cameras and still allow the laptop screen to fold properly (a bit tight on new Apple MacBook Pros)

Printer:

Creality CR-10S

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.15

Infill:

100%

Notes:

The parts are pretty thin so to build up enough layers i printed it at 0.15. 0.1 would be better if your printer is capable.

Take the sliding shutter part and flex it into the detents on one end of the mount - these lead into the slider rails in the base. It might be a bit tight to slide in but once snapped into place, it should provide smooth operation. Put double sided tape (I use that gummy carpet tape). Cut the tape out of the pass-through hole and mount in front of any webcam.

Depending on how well set up your printer is, you may need to run a knife lightly down the slots on the base part to ensure they are clear enough to allow smooth sliding of the shutter
This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/0M1Gjtb9m5R

A diamond or, rather, a dodecahedron of 12 congruent triangular faces.

It is derived from the cube-based Kawai half-cube joint. Two copies make a nice-looking diamond. It can also be assembled with a half-cube for a nonahedron (9-faced polyhedron; gosh, what a name!). It makes an appealing desktop toy. I think kids may love it for its aesthetic values. It is easy to print without any support or raft. Have fun!

Update: I tried the "diamond" with a child, who immediately started spinning it between his fingers and further recommended that a stand be made so his fingers wouldn't hurt. And it turned out to be a great idea!

remixed_from.author: somcalmetim
remixed_from.title: CR-10 Dial Indicator Mount for X-Axis Rail

title: CR-10 Harbor Freight Dial Indicator Mount for X-Axis

description.text:
This is a remix of a simple Dial Indicator Mount that slides over the x-axis extrusion. Remixed original file and remade in Fusion 360 to add a little more stability and to make this fit the Pittsburgh 1" Travel Machinist's Dial Indicator that can be purchased at Harbor Freight.

Allows bed leveling from an auto-home position with no need for g-code setup routines. Just use move axis in prepare menu choose 1mm. Move Z-Axis up about 25 to mount and then move Z-Axis back down until it touches so you can zero it out. Then you can move the Y-Axis to desired points to check for level. Move mount along the X-Axis and repeat for the bed where you would like to check for level.

Printed in PLA. This was tested on my CR-10S and worked great (This was the 3rd attempt on the design). I made this to fit tightly onto the x-axis and found that the retaining bar was not really necessary but it does lock it in and there is no wobble on the dial. The mount will not slide freely along the x-axis bar with the retaining bar without considerable force. It slides freely without it in you just have to pull it out a little and then you can slide it to where you want it and press it back on to lock in place. MAKE SURE YOU PUSH YOUR X-AXIS BELT UP WHEN MOUNTING THIS SO YOU DO NOT SNAG IT AND STRETCH IT OUT. Some light sanding was necessary on the bottom of the opening for the x-axis to fit, but I have adjusted this in the stl, but may still be necessary. Sanding will also be needed on the retaining bar if you choose to use it to make it slide nicely in the slot. No sanding should be necessary on the pin. Depending on your particular printer settings and tolerances this could vary.

I have included the S3D Factory Files and the gcode I used to print mine. The gcode is from S3D using the Chris Elkin's profile. Printed at 210 nozzle and 60 bed. Your settings may vary, but that is what the gcode is set to.

Printer:

Creality CR-10S

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

85% for Pin /35%-80% for mount and bar

Notes:

Raft is suggested for the Pin to give more surface area. The mounting block and retaining bar do not need them.

Supports are needed on the Dial Mount Block so that holes and slot remain true.

Infill for the pin is suggested to be at least 80% so it doesn't break in half.

Infill for block on mine was 85% so the bottom tab under the X-Axis wouldn't break off when pushing it all the way on but would probably be fine at 35%-50%.

Was printed at 210 nozzle and 60 bed.

Usage instructions:
1) Push the printed part in the accessory slot
2) Place fabric to be hemmed into the J-shaped opening
3) Using a wide needle setting run the machine making sure the folded fabric stays inside the opening

author: allanglen

title: 12 mm thru-axle to 9 mm quick release inserts

description.text:
NOT FOR 3D PRINTING

These are inserts designed to interface with the fork that comes with the Fuji Jari series, allowing you to run quick release wheels in front. The rear already converts between 12 x 142 thru-axle & QR 135 mm. It is a 12 x 100 mm thru-axle (TA) fork, with 1.5 mm thread pitch.

The idea is that while the over-locknut dimension (OLD) is 100 mm on 99% of front quick release (QR) wheels, the M9 x 1 mm hub axle itself is nominally 108 mm wide. Standard QR forks have a slot (hence dropout) to allow the hub to slide into position. You can mount a 108 mm hub in your fork by spreading each leg outward a hair over 4 mm on each side.

Everything you do is at your own risk. I tested a front QR hub fit on this Fuji carbon fork
(spreading it manually & all) without much issue.

No idea whether or not this is compatible with similar forks.

Turned out on a lathe, then cut the 12 mm hex flats with a mill. I would not recommend this for 3D printing. I've shared the SLDPRT & SLDDRW files for your reference. The drawings have been updated since I last machined the parts.

You may need a rear (read: longer) QR skewer since the effective clamping width is going to be much longer.

Dimensions in inch/mm since I was working in a machine shop with an imperial DRO.

Untested. I am still waiting to cut the M12 x 1.5 threads on the driveside insert.

Bunch of pictures I used for reference are included.

https://www.parktool.com/blog/repair-help/basic-thread-concepts#article-section-6 Front QR hub axles are M9 x 1 mm. QR skewers are M5 x 0.8 mm AFAIK. I included a very rough QR skewer & hub axle CAD for reference.

Both inserts are drilled out 6 mm deep since the hub axle protrudes nominally 4 mm beyond the OLD.

I listed a bunch of imperial drill bits closest to the 5 mm QR skewer & 9 mm QR hub axle close clearance fit - I ended going with #8 & letter T bits respectively with excellent fit results.

For reference, a Shimano FH-M615 hub specs about 5.3 mm clearance for the skewer (as opposed to about 5.05 mm with these inserts) - so much larger tolerances are acceptable.

I went with 12 mm hex flats since a 12 mm wrench is pretty close to not clearing the fork dropout geometry. I don't have a hex broach for socket options, & milling hex flats is very easy. This may be problematic as there's not much material to sit on the driveside, as you might be able to tell in the photos.

Hex flats are 6 mm tall since McMaster tells me thin M12 nuts are 6 mm tall. I reused this dimension arbitrarily for the slip insert.

Slip insert (unthreaded non-driveside) has a large-ish chamfer so you can pry it off with a slotted screwdriver should it get stuck for any reason.

Untested OD for the M12 x 1.5 thread. I have read that usually the nominal diameter - 0.005" is usually sufficient, or 98%. I will test with the former.

I did not end up cutting the thread gutter this time. This would be more helpful if you were to turn the threads on a lathe, but I'm not sure if it's useful for a manual die operation.

comments.text: Keep up the great work! I have printed all of your shells/grenades, and they decorate my desk nicely! I'd like to suggest for you're next project is to model an APFSDS-T penetrator/petals and have the life sized model and 1/3 scale it, similar to your 125mm shell, posted. The HEATFS shell (presumably from the T-64) is very cool and is the best thing on my desk I've got so far. The same tank also, as you probably know, also fires APFSDS-T, and I'm sure you could find some specifications and/or blueprints on one of the most common tanks' APFSDS-T. I only suggest this to you because I have been looking around everywhere and I cannot seem to find an APFSDS penetrator anywhere, real of reproduction, as I think it would be a perfect thing to put on my desk to quench my unrelenting interest in tanks and their ammo. license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: I have a standing Ottlite on which the mounting arm attaching the lamp head to the support bars was broken. Enter my 3D printer... I designed the replacement mounting arm using (yes, of all things and some will cringe) 3D Builder. After a trip to Lowes for hardware to connect it all up (about $5 in hardware (I bought way more than I needed - oh well). It is very stable and is holding up great.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator+

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

200 mils

Infill:

50%

Notes:

I always print with a raft because I get better results doing so, so the raft can be at your discretion. I set supports because I wanted to ensure the larger bolt hole was printed to the best results. I used 50% infill to get the rigidity I wanted for strength. It was printed using Robo3D Rocket Red PLA filament.

Smaller Bolt Hole

The smaller bolt hole is a tight fit for the OEM bolt; however, I did that by design to ensure there was minimal play and would provide a good tight fit.

Large Bolt Hole

For replacing the large bolt, I replaced the OEM bolt with a 3/8" x 2 1/2" bolt with some flat washers and a locking nut with a nylon ring inset in the nut.

description.text:
An enclosure for wireless DMX modules (often available on ebay). The enclosure has been designed to be screwed directly on to a female 3 pin XLR connector (M17x1.0 thread).



Also, a DC connector is added, so that the module can be powered by an external 5V power supply (for example an USB charger).

Links to parts on eBay

Wireless DMX Module

Female Chassis mount DC Power connector

USB to DC adapter cable (straight)
USB to DC adapter cable (angled)
M3x12 screws

Assembly instructions
First insert the DC power connector in the base part, and tighten the nut on the DC connector on the inside.

Next, the antenna for the DMX module need to be mounted. Mount the antenna connector to the EndCap piece, and tighten the nut on the SMA connector. Now glue the EndCap to the body.

Now it is time to mount up the wires and do some soldering.

WARNING: Do NOT trust the colors on the wires on the plug/cable delivered with the module.
Check the attached picture for how the connections were on my modules (my markings with red text). I relocated the wires in the JST plug, so the coloring made more sense.
First, solder the power connections to the DC connector - remember to have an extra wire soldered to the negative pin of the DC connector - it should be used for the XLR connector.
Next, pass the D+, D- and GND wire through the hole in the end of the body, through the XlrPlug piece (remember to orient it correctly) and through the XlrRing piece. Solder the 3 wires to the 3 pins in on the XLR connector.
Pin 1 of the XLR is GND
Pin 2 of the XLR is D-
Pin 3 of the XLR is D+

Now assemble the XLR plug part. Insert the XlrRing into the XLR connector housing together with the XLR plug piece. Then tighten the XlrPlug piece to the back of the XLR connector.
Now carefully try to assemble everything. Connect the antenna to the PCB, and then JST plug to the PCB.The antenna cable can be located under the PCB and go back up - avoid to bend it too much, it will cause signal loss!
You might want to secure the PCB temporarily with a couple of screws while you glue the XLR connector piece together with the body. Once everything is in place, you can remove the temporary screws from the PCB, make sure the PCB is in place - put the lid on the top of the body, and tighten everything together with 4 M3x12mm screws. will fit better.

Contributions are appreciated - it took me quite some time to get the design made in Fusion360, and a lot of test prints..

If you print a part, please remember to post a "make" picture

Update 2018-02-07: Improved body, lid and endcap added as version 2.1. XLR-Ring and and XLR-Plug parts are still the same.

Notes:

Many parts require support, including the Vertical Stabilizer Assembly, Engines 1 & 3, the Inner & Outer Wings, and the Wing Supporting Structures. Orientations should be correct from the STL's, but in the event they are not, use the following:
Engines 1 and 3 with the intake facing up (Yes, this results in the side with the tiny contact area touching the bed. I know, trust me)
Vertical Stabilizer: Vertically, as if it where on the plane.
Outer Wings: Inner side down, so the support tower holds up the winglet
Inner wings: Inner side down. This doesn't need much, but the mating surface is NOT flat.
Wing Supporting Structures: Same as on the airplane. Will require support all along bottom.
All other pieces: Any other pieces should NOT require support, as they all have a flat bottom. To make assembly easier, I would recommend printing the models vertically, so the parts will sit closer to each other once put together. Vertical= 1/2 Circle part on bed.
Just another quick note. The windows for the cockpit are quite small, and I would recommend printing them at as high a resolution as possible, just so the layer lines aren't too obvious, as they are right on the front of the plane here.

Assembly

All smaller pieces that slot into the main frame are undersized by .3mm, for a friction fit on most 3d printers. If this is too loose, I would recommend gluing it in, which is a good idea for the whole frame in general. This goes for parts like the engines, the wings, and the vertical and horizontal stabilizers, where they sit into another part. The cockpit windows have a slightly smaller clearance, but should still fit, as they are only held on 2 or 3 sides.
Before you slot any of the smaller parts together, I would assemble the main pieces, such as the fuselage and wings. Once that is all together, you can attach the other pieces.
This was designed using Fusion 360, working off original drawings of the MD-11. One was set up for each plane, allowing me to get reference measurements for all axes.

comments.text:
It's good you have split the model to be more printer-friendly.
But from my experience the top of the cylinders if printed horizontally will suffer from the resolution settings. Regardless of the setting you will always see the layers on the curvature.
It is better to print cylindrical fuselages oriented vertically without the necessity to split them horizontally. There is no benefit of such split.

print_settings.Notes:: The need for supports depends on what parts you are printing. Parts are based on a 220mm x 220mm bed, of which I use 210mm. I laid the arm in at 45° in the xy plane and tilted up 20° from horizontal, as shown in the pics. It requires a lot of support and takes about 8 hours to print. The frame base pieces took the longest. I printed both at once and it was about a 10 hour print. The side frames I laid flat and printed one at a time with support, they take bout 6 hours each. I got some warping on them but it didn't affect function. I would recommend prtinting the wheel parts and the ball 1 at a time at slower speeds.

description.text:
This is an f2k style floating arm trebuchet. The frame stands about 8" tall by 12" long. It can easily launch the small golf ball included in the files a good 25-30 feet with the right sling/pin and counterweight. This must be printed in pieces and assembled, with some hardware and other items required for assembly. Press fits are designed for 608-2rs bearings.

What to print:
Base_front 1x
Base_rear 1x
Frame parts 1 of each (4 total)
Arm 1x
Top pieces 2x
Trigger shaft 1x
Trigger wheel 1x
Wheel 1 1x (optional)
Wheel 2 1x (optional)
Wheel 3 2x (optional)
Wheel 4 2x (optional)
Ball As many as you want (optional)

What to Buy:
M8x150mm threaded rod 1x (I used the one from the spool holder that came with my printer)
M8x80mm bolt 1x
M8 washers 4x (to retain any larger washers used for counterweight)
M8 nut 9x
Large washers 10-14x (25-40mm outside diamter, for counterweight)
Thread 2meters or so, for sling
Cloth 40x80mm ish, I used microfiber, for sling
Paper clips 2x (medium-large size)
M4 or M5 washer 1x (for sling to pin connection)
608-2rs bearings 3x

Assembly:
If you printed the wheels (I really didn't notice much of a difference in performance with or without them, they probably help a bit with keeping the arm centered on the frame) then snap them onto the bearings. Press two of the bearings with the small wheels onto the arm shafts. The other one goes on the M8 bolt at the rear of the frame. The frame is intended to be pressed together. Center the M8 threaded rod on the arm and retain it with nuts. Add counterweight. Slide it into the center slots on the frame and install the top pieces. For the pin, cut a 50mm long piece of paperclip, heat it up with a lighter, and press it into the small hole on the end of the arm. You will need to play with the length and angle of the pin to get the ideal throwing arc. For the trigger, use another paperclip and bend it/ cut it to the proper length. The sling is a rectangular piece of cloth with holes in each corner, and 150-200mm thread doubled up for each side. One side of the sling is attached to the thru hole at the end of the arm, the other is attached to a small washer that goes around the pin on the end of the arm. You'll figure it out.

title: Ultimate Pi Zero W emulator machine inside SNES Cartridge

description.text:
This is a 1 day project I did. All 3D printed pieces were designed and printed in the same day and the whole machine was also assembled during that same day. At around 10:30PM I was playing games on it.

If you want to build one for youself, what you'll need is:

  • 1x MicroUsbBracket.stl
  • 1x USBPortsBracket.stl
  • 2x PiZeroBracket.stl
  • 1x Raspberry Pi Zero W
  • 1x Raspberry Pi Copper heatsink (the copper ones have a lower profile)
  • 1x Micro SD card (at least 8GB)
  • RetroPie Image for Raspberry Pi Zero
  • 4x M2 Threaded brass metal inserts (Can be salvaged from old laptops)
  • 4x M2 Screws, at least 5mm long and at most 7mm long. (can be found with the brass inserts)
  • 1x Mini-HDMI to HDMI cable adapter. 1 foot long or shorter, the shorter the better.
  • 2x Small cable tie
  • 4x USB type A ports
  • 1x USB micro port. (also include some heatshrink that fits around it. The bracket for the USB micro port was designed for a very tight fit when heatshrink is used)
  • 1x 4-port NanoHub
  • 1x SNES cartridge of your choice (can be found on ebay for varying prices)
  • (if damaged SNES catridge) SNES replacement game stickers
  • A bunch of 22AWG wires of different colors (red, black, green and white for standard usb colors)
  • Solder and soldering iron
  • Utility knife or rotary tool (for modding the cartridge)
  • (not requiered but useful) Solder sucker
  • A LOT OF PATIENCE. This project requieres to solder extremely tiny solder holes/pads, so take your time and never go faster than you think you can.

Notes:

HDMI adapter might need to be trimmed down to flatten it so it can fit in the cartridge.

Catridge needs to be moddified at many places inside:

  • Cut away the middle support.
  • Cut all walls in the connector opening.
  • Remove the corner supports
  • Might need to remove the extra supports on the tabs of the top cover, you'll see if you can't close it.

All 3D printed pieces are held in place using super glue. The USB ports are reinforced from the inside with hot glue and the HDMI female end of the adapter is glued to the catridge using super glue after flattening its surface.

Threaded brass inserts are inserted in the brackets by placing them on top of the holes in the brackets and then pushing into them with a soldering iron that is turned on. After the brass heats up (takes about 5 seconds) it will start sinking inside the PLA piece very easily. Simply push them down until they are flat with the top of the pieces or push them down a bit lower, since the brackets were designed so that longer screws can be used.

Solder 2 cables to the Micro USB port, one for 5V+ and one for GND, then add the heatshrink around it and heat it up. Once assembled, simply pass the wires through the hole of the bracket and push the port inside until it's flat with the wall. Make sure you insert it in the correct orientation, because it's almost impossible to get the port out of the hole without damaging it once it's fully inserted.

You will probably need to a pair of small tweezers to take the micro sd card in and out of the pi zero. Don't force it, it can break and ruin your whole raspberry pi board.

Extra Notes:

I purposely do not talk about how you should wire the USB hub or the USB ports and which pads you should solder to on the raspberry pi zero because I believe that this kind of project should only be done by people who understand how these things work and how to solder properly (even if my soldering isn't that good). All missing information to build this project is easy to find with some quick research on Google, so if you're not able to find the information I purposely didn't mention here on your own, then maybe this project is too advanced for you. I'm open to helping others build this if they ask it in the comments, but this is a learning experience and you should go through it all if you want to understand how all of these things work.

title: K8200 / 3DRAG Holder for simply replace an extruder
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Dit is een houder voor K8200, om eenvoudig de complete extruder te vervangen zonder te moeten solderen. Gemakkelijk om bv de huidige te vervangen door direct drive exturder, of extra originele exturder te monteren voor ABS gebruik. Zo hoef je ook niet telkens de hotend af te regelen. En kan je PLA en ABS gescheiden houden.  
This is a holder for replacement of a complete extruder in a simply way without need to solder. Easy to replace for example: a direct drive exturder or similar original exturder for use ABS only (so you don't mix PLA and ABS in same hotend. You can separate PLA and ABS). So you do not always adjust the hotend.

description.text:
I got a black Leatherman Tread (knockoff) and didn't want to pay for ChronoLinks nor be stuck with very rough adjustments by removing full or half-sized links. So, I first just designed an pin to adapt the Garmin Fenix's 2.5mm pin to the 3.5mm holes on the Tread's link brackets. Then I designed full links with arms to allow for high-resolution size adjustments. This is my first thing, so if you find it useful or have suggestions please let me know.

The designs are fully parameterized so that they can be adjusted to other watches and wrists. Note that the skinny parts of the arms are adjustable in height as a compromise to add strength to what I think is the weakest part of the design - the large holes where the link attaches to the Tread links.

I've been wearing the links for about three weeks now and when printed in black PETG with a black Leatherman Tread, the links are unnoticeable.

description.text:

title: Divider for Dewalt DWST14825 DEEP PRO ORGANIZER

description.text:
I purchased a few of the Dewalt Deep Organizers to organize a bunch of screws and fasteners I had taking up too much space in my garage and not very organized.

I discovered I had many different screws in too many thread types but not the quantity to fill up the bins. So I designed these dividers to divide the bins to hold more specific types of screws.

These dividers definitely will maximize the use of these organizers without needed to purchase an unnecessary quantity of organizers .

Future plans:
Create dividers for the larger bins, but the length will push the bounds of my printer even when arranged on a diagonal.

Background

Design

I used calipers to measure the bins to design the divider and printed about 3 different versions before I got the fit correct. This 4th version was perfect. I can print 6 at a time when positioned vertically.

title: Three 37D Motor Mount Variations (Like Pololu Gearmotor)

description.text:
For whatever reason I had to make another 37D Motor Mount (I guess I like these motors)

In the middle of building it, I had mounts for one side and realized that some applications may need only that. So I went ahead and provided "one sided mount" versions as well.

The slots are intended for M4 or #8 screws. (If you need a bigger screw than that your design may have bigger problems!)

For my purpose I needed a model of the motor as well, so I included that. (Most motor manufacturers have models you can download, though the formats might be odd - nowadays there are online format converters available though).

Full disclosure: Gearbest gave me the CR-10 that I printed this with, so I feel sort of obligated to put it through it's paces.

0.16 layer height

Infill:

not critical

Notes:

I printed this sideways (as oriented in the STL) to take advantage of the maximum strength characteristics. I used a 0.4 nozzle, with 0.8 extrusion width. I set the layer outline/perimeter shells to 7 so it is essentially solid hence infill settings are not critical. These last two settings are critical for strength. Top and bottom layer quantities are not critical either. 0.8mm width and 0.16 layer height seem to give great strength results.
Keep your speed down make sure your extrusion multiplier is adequate.
Not much to do except remove the supports, maybe finish or clean up any edges etc.

remixed_from.title: Toy 1:10 H015 Sentry Droid (Star Wars: The Force Awakens & The Last Jedi)

title: Toy 5.5% Scale Mouse Droid (About 3.75" figure sized)

description.text:
After building the 1:10 Sentry Droid I figured I just had to do this - because...

...but the toy that comes with General Hux is probably better.

Because of the small size I had to take liberty with the details, so the greeblies aren't accurate, but I think they're decent for the scale. The "body" and wheels are to scale.

This model was built from scratch by me...

Included .3mf, .stl, and my sketchup file - the sketchup isn't great though (it hates small sizes), so if you reexport from that, it'd also need repaired.

It's a pain to print with the detail, I'd recommend just going out and buying the General Hux figure toy that comes with a mouse droid,

Full disclosure: Gearbest gave me the CR-10 that I printed this with, so I feel sort of obligated to put it through it's paces.

Printer:

Creality CR-10

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

Low

Notes:

You can print with low infill, this isn't load bearing. You could probably even print 0%, maybe add a top layer for that.

The little details are a serious pain to get to print. Simplify 3D refused to show some of the structure in the top greebles and the heat sinks on the side. Not sure why since they're less than the nozzle size.

So, I ended up telling Simplify 3D that I had a .2mm nozzle (instead of a .4mm) and to use a multiplier of 2x. That's probably too much plastic, but it seemed to work...

It didn't print well all-in-one, so I chopped it up, it'll need glued together. The bottom has a little lip which I left in and likely needs support. I added a support by hand because it's so tiny most slicers aren't going to like that lip. However there's a no-support bottom as well.

The details are the biggest problem. Good luck, this is tricky. Just go buy a General Hux figure with the toy mouse, that'd be a lot easier!

title: Ceiling/ Wall Mount for Fibaro Multisensor

description.text:
Be aware that I adapted the inner diameter of the "hole" for the motion sensor to have it come out the proper size on my printer.

I recommend printing a few layers and then check if your sensor fits into the opening at the base of the holder. If not, simply adjust the size of the holder in your slicer and try again. But don´t be to generous with enlarging, it has to be a tight fit or the sensor will fall out.

For horizontal installation at the ceiling the sensor stays in place by gravity alone but if you use it vertically it might be a good idea to simply stuff some tissue paper behind it (doesn´t hurt for horizontal installation either) to keep it in place.

description.text:
This Thing contains a set of .stl files for industrial walkways designed to be used between larger pieces of sci-fi wargame terrain. The platforms are 25mm square, and in lengths of 50mm, 75mm and 100mm. Included is a set of legs and angle pieces that can be clipped to the platforms to support them between terrain. The platforms can also be clipped together to extend their length, and there are also two varieties of hand rail included.

There is also a set of 50mm, 75mm and 100mm platforms that are ridged. These, along with the two ramp pieces allow you to build a 30 degree ramp that figures can be placed on without sliding down.

For more designs and 28mm war gaming terrain check out my blog: http://www.tabletop-terrain.com

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.1

Infill:

10%

Notes:

Supports: Supports are NOT be required for the platforms themselves. Supports are only required for the 'LeftAngle', 'RightAngle', 'Connector', 'SupportLeg', 'RampRight' and 'RampLeft' .stl files.

Assembly: The pieces are designed for a tight friction fit. Some filing of the clip and support pieces may be required during assembly. Gluing is recommended as well.

The 'CommonClip' piece will have to be printed multiple times for each platform, as one is required to hold each angle, connector or leg piece to a platform.

My daughters love their American Girl and Our Generation dolls, and needed a small doll-sized closet for hanging their clothes and storing their accessories. Instead of spending $60 to $80 or more for a purpose-built wardrobe, we purchased a ClosetMaid 8982 Stackable 2-Door Organizer, readily available from Amazon or the local Home Depot. We placed the adjustable shelves towards the top and bottom of the unit, and inserted an inexpensive rubber-tipped, twist-type, friction-fit curtain rod from which to hang the clothes.

We quickly discovered that friction alone was not sufficient to support the rod with the weight of the doll clothes hanging from it. So, I designed these simple closet rod flanges to support the rod at either end. The part is slightly over-built to withstand rugged play from excited girls yanking clothes off of hangars. I suggest 100% infill. You will need to print 2 parts.

This part can also be used anywhere else you need to hang a small curtain rod, or other type of similarly-sized rod. We used these curtain rods in our kitchen windows when I was growing up, and small rod flanges would have been very handy to keep the rods from occasionally falling down.

Link to ClosetMaid 8982 Stackable 2-Door Organizer:
https://smile.amazon.com/gp/product/B002IT6E74/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o01_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

The part was modeled in AutoCAD 2002, and modeled like similar closet rod flanges for full-sized closet rods. The Gcode was generated in Cura 15.02.1-1.03

I have uploaded both the stl file, and the original AutoCAD file.

The flanges are held in place by a single wood screw, either a No. 4, 1/2-inch long wood screw, or a 3 mm diameter wood screw. I drilled a 1/4-inch deep 1/16th inch pilot hole on the left and right inside walls, centered front to back, 2 inches from the underside of the top shelf.

The hole is sized to hold the screw so you can get it started and screw it through the part so it is sticking out the back about 1/8th of an inch; this makes it much easier to finish screwing the part in place.

The u-shaped cradle that supports the end of the rod is sized so that the rubber tip gently snaps into place.

author: cncope

description.text:
That thing got a hemi?
chug, chug, chug, VROOOM, chug, chug, chug, Squeeeeealll!!!
A larger version of my v8 motor, designed with the Replicator in mind.
The body is 225mm long so it should just fit the HBP of a Replicator. The pistons are 43mm (BIG, that's like a 50cc chainsaw motor!) and they connect with printed cylinders instead of filament. I also made all the moving parts with much tighter tolerances (.25+/-mm) so it requires a fairly fine tuned machine. I have also included smaller pistons in case they need to be smaller. I tried to keep the plastic needed to a minimum by designing it with thinner walls, radius edges and relief details but still be well detailed and robust. This also will help keep the print time to a minimum.

All files should slice cleanly, I had some problems and learned how to fix them. No more naked edges or intersecting meshes. Just nice clean STLs; though they do take a while to slice.
Settings.
I think printing it with an extra shell or two with 20% infill for the body and pistons would be fine but the crank and connectors should be printed with a higher infill, 60-100% so you can manipulate the parts if needed.
Print the pistons and connectors first. then put them together.
Print the crank and spacers next then assemble crank spacers and pistons as seen in the images DON"T put the end axles in yet!!
Print the body then assemble the piston/crank assembly into the body sections and carefully glue the two body sections together.
Now insert the axles carefully into the ends of the crank. The motor should work at this point.
Print the reinforcement fins and glue them into the valley of the body sections as seen in the images.
Then print and install the crank handle.
My individual print times were as follows:
Body sections printed two at once and took 31 hours.
Connectors took 5 hours
Spacers were 4 hours 15 minutes.
Pistons took 16 hours (I printed the 42.5mm)
Crank 6 hours.
Crank handle 1 hour 30 minutes
Reinforcements 3 hours
Total print time: 66 hours 45 minutes.
It turned out amazing! Here is a couple of videos, http://youtu.be/wASI4fyEOT4 this one shows it before some extras and this one shows it after, http://youtu.be/Pf1OogRw3oQ

comments.text: Hmm, you could  try lowering the layer height to .2 and increase the temperature to 225 or 230 degrees on the extruder and 115-120 on the HBP. This should help your layer fusion. Although completely satisfied with the journal I created. My son soon suggested that I should make the doors open individually. As a book this would be very difficult and complicated to do, so I created a box.

I have reworked my original design. The handles in the original proved to be too thin and broke when I tried to insert the wood beam. I have since improved this, but have not yet printed the new design.

As with the original you will need to use supports for the handles.

Some assembly is required. the door frame needs to be glued to the box and the doors slotted into place.

to finish off, i grabbed a pic of the internet to stick in the bottom of the box.

although i have provided an STL for the whole thing it is not intended to be printed in this way and should be printed in it's individual parts.

Sorry if i caused any confusion

description.text:
I fixed this model as it would not print as there were so many issues with it. When you take one preview look in the slicer it was a disaster and would never print. However this is a great model so I removed all the corals out in thin air and then fixed or the intersections and put the "Benchy" part back together so it would print as it had multiple parts that did not really exist. I then made the model into a single structure and now it works like a charm.

I fixed this model so I could make up another remix from it

Printer:

Tevo Little Monster

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1

Infill:

35%

Notes:

Do not allow it to add automatic supports.

My delta printed this no problem without supports under the cabin (not sure how as it is printing way out in thin air) but none of my cartesian would, so add some little manual supports under the cabin to allow the bridging to take place, I made enough space to make it easy to remove them afterwards. If you want all the coral fronds to work you will need to add some manual supports in 2 areas (see pics), it will print fine if you don't and the wayward bits of plastic from the lack of supports are super easy to remove after the print is done.

Print it at 0.1mm or lower layer height and super slow if you want all the detail on the coral fronds (which is the parts that make this look so cool). Be extra careful removing from the bed as the corals connect everything together.

This is a geneva drive made for the BlocksCAD Snowflake challange (#BlocksCADSnowflake). It is designed like a snowflake, so that one rotation of the outter wheel will cause the Snowflake to rotate 60°, because snowflakes are in any case hexagonal (caused by the molecular constellation of both hydrogen an oxygen atoms). A geneva drive has an inner wheel and an an outer wheel, a pin on the outter wheel rotates in a notch in the inner wheel and lets the inner one rotate for a certain amount of degrees (depending on the shape). the inner rotation is not continious, while the outter one is. Ths mechanism is used for example in old film projectors to show picture after picture in a certain cadenza.

An dieser Stelle mal vielen Dank an xxricsxx für die Bereitstellung der ganzen Daten.
Ich habe das Ganze etwas weiter getrieben und mein Ziel - möglichst alle Originalteile zu verwenden - erreicht.
Vor allem die Buchsen für Hotend und Heatbed konnte ich integrieren. Des Weiteren scheint mein Display etwas anders von den Maßen her zu sein und daher habe ich das Backcover mittels Tinkercad angepasst.
Für den Umbau werden noch ein paar Nutensteine und M5x8 sowie M5x10 Schrauben benötigt. Ansonsten müssen nur das Kabels des X-Endstops sowie Zuleitungen vom Netzteil verlängert werden.

Thanks a lot to xxricsxx for providing all the data.
I have done a little bit further and achieved my goal - to use as many original parts as possible.
Especially the sockets for Hotend and Heatbed I could integrate. Furthermore, my display seems to be slightly different in terms of dimensions and therefore I have adapted the back cover using Tinkercad.
For the conversion still a few T-nuts and M5x8 and M5x10 screws are needed. Otherwise, only the cable of the X-Endstops and supply lines of the power supply must be extended.

description.text: Created this figurine for a friend at work as we do a lot of specialist consultation for Government Departments and they are full of people who "Know Boats". They all think they are "Subject Matter Experts" on so many things (despite you being brought in as the "Expert" due to not having one) yet hold no qualification and demonstrate neither an understanding of the subject nor the level of an expert on the matters discussed. As a result we find ourselves constantly referencing to the saying "I Know Boats" so I made this up. The irony here is the boat has sunken and is in parts but you still want to claim that "I know Boats".

title: Customizeable Drawer Divider / Drawer Organizer
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I was asked by a relative wether it is possible to print customized drawer dividers and so I tried and created this thing. You can custiomize the dividers fully to your needs by using the scad file provided.

The different settings are explained in the scad file, the instruction schema that comes with the files and the following:

  • Divider_Length: The main length of the divider from the edges or the center of the overlap regions.
  • Left_Top_Connector: Wheter to create a linear connector on the left / top side of the divider.
  • Left_Top_Connector_Inverted: Wether to invert the left / top connector.
  • Right_Bottom_Connector: Wheter to create a linear connector on the right / bottom side of the divider.
  • Right_Bottom_Connector_Inverted: Wether to invert the right / bottom connector.

  • Positions_Connectors: The positions of the slits for connecting vertical and horizontal dividers. This is an array in the form [Pos1, Pos2, Pos3 ...] counted from the left / top side of the divider.

  • Divider_Height: The height of the divider.
  • Divider_Thickness: The thickness of the divider (Should be an even multiplicative of your desired layer height)
  • Overlap_Length: The length of the overlap region for linear connectors.
  • Diameter_Connectors: The diameter of the round alignment knobs and holes on the linear connectors.
  • Amount_Connectors: The amount of knobs to create on linear connectors. (Their type is alternating a knob or a hole)
  • Ignore_Problems: Wether to ignore problems with the settings that could influence the divider functionality.

If you need to create a part with linear connectors on both sides, one of these should be inverted to make the divider printable. Note: All left / top non inverted connectors match with all right / bottom non inverted connectors and all left / top inverted connectors match with all right / bottom inverted connectors, but inverted and non inverted connectors don't match.

The example stl files in the file section are the parts of the divider I printed for my relative. They are created for a 295mm x 425mm drawer.

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Doesn't matter

Infill:

50% or more

Notes:

You can add rafts if your suffering from warping. The layer height doesn't matter, but should be an even quotient of the Divider_Thickness. If the knobs of the linear connectors are on the downside of the model, flip it by 180°.
The linear connectors are supposed to be glued together. Afterwards you can stick the dividers together at their slit connectors and voila.

title: Torch mount for Draeger and similar helmets
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A helmet mount for LED Lenser T7M and similar LED torches.

Fits the Draeger HPS 4100 and the HPS 4300 universal mount (and probably most other universal mounts, as far as i know of).
The Draeger HPS 4300/4100 is handed out to german firefighters and members of the german federal agency for technical relief, as well as to other civil defense agencies.

Both mounts were tested successfully ands fit nicely.

Printing instructions:

  • Best results with 20% carbon filament @0.1mm resolution with a 0.4mm nozzle, needs about 6m filament for the larger mount
  • PLA won't work because it's way to brittle, ABS had problems with breaking while inserting the flashlight
  • The universal mount is best printed with the mounting plate facing downwards without raft
  • The Draeger mount prints nicely sidewards, so the walls of the torch holder are vertical.
    Prints best with 2 raft layers and a little support.

The draeger version can be used upside down, keeping the torch safer and from hanging into branches and things ;)

DISCLAIMER:
Be aware that this is no official accessory to your helmet and might cause legal issues in case of an accident!
The LED Lenser torches are in no respect rated for explosive environments, this is what the orginal UK 4AA should be used for.
Use this at your own risk!

title: A little standing Porg
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Here it is, a little standing Porg.

I started this sculpt and did most of it back in August, but the time passed and I forgot about it.

This Porg is based in concept sketches from the last Star Wars movie.

In the photos there are other different Porgs, those were the test subjects to get to the perfect standing Porg. Lots of broken legs and stuff.

So yes, virtual animals were harmed in the production of the perfect little standing Porg.

UPDATE - 22/01/2018

In case your Porg's leg gets broken, everything is ok. In the spirit of Star Wars, I added a lightsaber prosthetic leg so your Porg can stand up again and conquer the galaxy.

Printer:

Creality CR-10

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0,2 mm

Infill:

10%

Notes:

I printed at 60 mm/s, at 210º and 60º for the bed.

There is no need/gain from printing with higher details than 0,2mm, it's going to look exactly the same.

It's printed at 10% infill, but the first 32 layers are solid. The feet should be solid till the ankle, the number of layers depend on the print size.

The model is in the horizontal position, but it should be placed vertical when printing.

The supports are just needed below the Porg, in Simplify3D I chose 3mm for "Support Pilar Resolution" and 14% for "Support Infill Percentage". But I printed with supports at 2 and 4 mm and it works fine too. The last photo shows the supports in Simplify3D.

UPDATE - 22/01/2018

For the prosthetic leg, you need to print it vertically and scale it to your Porg's size.
Print it at 0,1 mm, 100% infill or have all the layers has "Bottom Solid Layers". 60 mm/s is ok.

author: Yote_x2

description.text:
Intent

My girlfriend wanted a "thing" to hold the paper roll in the kitchen and since I have a printer she asked if I could "make something" - Sure!

Obstacles

Because I wanted the construction to be heavy I figured I wanted it filled with something.
So I had to make it hollow and I also wanted a way to prevent the roll from coming off.
Another thought was that I wanted it to be printed without any support due to the the design.

Measurements

See "Paper roll holder blueprint.pdf"

Parts List

  • Top knob.stl
  • Threaded joint.stl
  • Lid with threaded shaft.stl
  • Bottom.stl

Required Hardware

  • 9 x M2.5x10 mm countersunk Phillips self tapping screws
  • 1 x M4x30 screw (from 25 to 35 mm is OK)
  • Sand or other heavy material

Assembly

Screw the "Lid with threaded shaft" part to the "Bottom" part and fill it up with sand.
A small way up the shaft is good.
Then use some kind of glue or stomp the shaft with a paper tissue to prevent the sand from going everywhere if it tips over.

Screw the "threaded Joint" to the "Top Knob" with the M4 screw and tighten fairly hard.
A good practice is to use a dab of CA glue between the two parts so it doesn't come loose when you unscrew and change the roll.

Footnote

Please let me know if you come up with a re-make of my creation.

Printer:

Anet AM8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

25

Notes:

Print everything in the same direction as seen in the finished product EXCEPT for the "Threaded joint" that needs to be printed with thread part facing up.
This part also need 35-50% infill.

Designed in Fusion 360

The file is uploaded if anyone need to change dimensions or want to do a remake.

description.text:
This is a fan duct for cooling the main board of an ultimaker 2.

Did you buy a door and ultitop to enclose your printer and had all long prints failing with mysterious under extrusion? I did. I figured the stepper motor drivers where overheating and thermally throttling thus loosing torque.

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.25mm

Infill:

100%

Notes:

Resolution and infill do not really matter. I printed it with 0.8mm nozzle with 100% infill with the original ultimaker 2 pla that came with the printer.

Assembly.

Get yourself some 50mm 12V fan (50x50x10). Mount it in the fan duct.
Get a buck converter. Connect the input of the buck converter to the 24V of the main board.Turn the potentiometer so that it outputs about 10V. Then connect the fan to the buck converter.
Tweak voltage to get an acceptable balance between fan noise and air flow. Turns out I got a silent fan at 12V.

Mounting.

Now comes the fun part. The fan duct has some bumps that fit the vent holes of the electronics box. That fixates the left side. At the other side, get some fitting M3x20 screw and lock nut. You should align the hole of the mount tab on the right to a pre-existing hole in your ultimaker.

Validate the installation by turning your ultimaker upright and turn it on. You should feel the slightest breeze of air on the right bottom side of the printer.

Enjoy your cooled main board!
Thanks to the .step files ultimaker provides you can design a fitting fan duct without any measuring.

Animated Parametric adjustable Tap Wrench

https://youtu.be/UOmYkc6I6Cw

I actually made one of these 40 years ago in my toolmaking apprenticeship and thought it would be a good example for testing the animation feature in OpenScad

The OpenScad file .... Tap_wrench_adjustable.scad is fully parametric so you can make your own design.

* Try this.. Test out the animation in this file **

To activate animation, select "View->Animation" from the
menu
You will see some input text boxes appear under the graphic simply
enter values into the appearing FPS and Steps input fields
(e.g. 5 FPS and 50 Steps for this animation).

Make sure you have the show=6 to show all the parts (without cover)

.... Typical parameters ......
max_adj_square=11; this is the maximum size the square will grow to
square=33; this is the square pocket the 4 segments fit into
thickness=11;
thread_dia=6; M6 thread
tap_hole_size=5; the tapping drill for M6
show=6;// 0=body 1=segment1 2=segment2 3=segment3 4=segment4 5=all parts 6=all with animation 7=just the cover

Please note if you go larger on the max_adj_square parameter you must also increase the square parameter which will automatically increase the segments.

I am intrigued if a tap wrench in plastic would ever work so watch this space as I will have to make one soon.

Please take the time to check out my other designs... Enjoy

title: Lens hood for Sony SAL24105 or Minolta AF 24-105mm F3.5-4.5 D

description.text:
This lens hood is designed for an tight fit in mechanical and optical aspects. It fits snugly over the lens if it is reversed, so it wouldn't be caught. The margin between the edges and the view port of is slightly over 1mm.

The mounting force is much less then with the original one. This can help to protect your lens if it is hit by something.

I hate most stock lens hoods, because they are way too bulky, the shape is rarely matched with the actual field of view and the fit is so hard that they enforce the risk of damaging the internal mechanisms of the lens.

The SAL24105 is Sony incarnation of the former Minolta AF 24-105mm F3.5-4.5 D. In my opinion it is the most vestibule one can find for full frame a mount. The only problem is that it is prone to flare. This lens hood will improve over the stock one.

It has marks for alignment in working position. In reverse position an twist of about 45° will secure it. In this position the stock one looks nicer.

One drawback of home made lens hoods are the glittering material. An narrow opening at the front helps to reduce this problem. Sanding and/or matt black paint might help also.

I used PETG.

title: A Stellated Icosahedral Snowflake
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a project that I have been envisioning for a long time. The underlying polyhedron is one of the 59 highly symmetric stellations of the icosahedron. This polyhedron surface is comprised of 60 congruent pentagonal faces. The faces come in 20 sets of 3 coplanar faces.

Each of the 60 faces is etched with one point of a fractal snowflake. Although the finished model looks solid it is hollow on the inside.

This thing was made with BlocksCAD

Edit this project at BlocksCAD: https://www.blockscad3d.com/editor?from=68087
Or, download the .xml file and load it at: https://www.blockscad3d.com/editor

The entire design comes from 60 copies of a single face. The module "face" creates a thick pentagon, and then subtracts from that two points of a fractal snowflake. The modules "Flake" and "Flake2" create the fractals.

In the picture below the piece that is on top, touching the z-axis, is the one that all the rest are generated from. I will discuss the second piece generated by rotating the top piece 120 degrees around the normal vector of the piece. The was accomplished with the "fancy rotate" block in BlocksCAD.

The first 2 pieces

Now focus on the top piece. We rotate 5 copies of that around the z axis to generate the top point.

Top point created

Then we rotate these 5 pieces around 180 degrees around the y-axis to generate the bottom point.

Bottom point added

Now we go back to the second piece that we in the first image. Rather than just rotating the first piece down there we rotate the whole top 5 pieces.

Third point created

This new point is now rotated around the z-axis to create 5 equally spaced points.

Point 4, 5, 6 and 7 added

These 5 points are then rotate 180 degrees around the y -axis to finish the model

The finished model

Please note that the images in this description are of a level 3 fractal, but the .stl file of this thing is a level 4 fractal.

If you load the blocks into BlocksCAD and render it yourself have patience. The level 4 fractal takes several hours to render.

description.text:
I wanted a sturdy frame mounted spool holder which used little filament to print. Also it had to clear a cable chain on the x-axis and have a mount for a filament guide. This is the end result, using just over 9gr. of filament with my settings.

This spool holder is compatible with this awesome filament guide and uses the included 20mm pvc pipe to hold a spool which snaps in place.

There are seperate prints for each side since they are tapered towards the end to save on filament. I've also inculded files without the mounting holes for the filament guide if someone wants that.

You should be able to attach the arms to the pre drilled holes which normally hold the lcd, use a nut in the slot behind. The holes for the filament guide are slightly smaller than the screw so they should self tap, otherwise you can use a nut to secure it more.
