This is a rework of the Z-Axis drive system to reduce the infamous z wobble and to increase Z resolution.

The 1:2 gearing allows print layers that are a multiple of 0.02 - 0.04, 0.08, 0.10, 0.12 etc. whereas the factory system allows for layers that are a multiple of 0.04 - 0.08, 0.10, 0.12 etc.

I have successfully printed down to a layer height of 0.04 with no noticeable Z-axis wobble.

Parts needed:

2x 20T 5mm bore GT2 pulley
2x 40T 8mm bore GT2 pulley
2x 150mm closed GT2 belt
4x 608zz bearings
2x 40mm M3 screws for top mount

Printed parts:

Motor plate (left and right). This fixes to existing motor mounting plate.

Top bearing holder (left and right). Keeps the lead screw in position at the top.

Bottom plate (left and right). This fixes underneath the existing motor mount plate using the holes for the motor. The Z smooth rod is supported by the motor itself in the original, this plate replaces that support.

The top z screw holder is based on this thing: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1858435

Aus Platzgründen und damit die bisherigen Schrauben weiter verwendet werden können, müssen die Löcher des Lüfters angepasst werden.
Hierzu mit einem 5,5 mm Bohrer die zwei Löcher am Lüfter von unten etwa 5 mm tief aufbohren. Von oben soweit bis der Schraubenkopf vollständig verschwindet.
Nicht komplett durchbohren, da sich der Lüfter sonst nicht festschrauben lässt.

The bracket allows the standard 50x10 mm fan to be replaced by a quieter/stronger 60x15 mm fan.
For space reasons and so that the previous screws can be used further, the holes of the fan must be adjusted.
To do this, use a 5.5 mm drill to drill down the two holes on the fan from below about 5 mm deep. From above until the screw head disappears completely.
Do not drill completely because the fan cannot be screwed.
If the screws do not find a stop, it can help if you re-drill the screw holes with a 2.5 mm drill.

title: Armattan Rooster TBS unify Pro HV and FC mount.

description.text:
TBS Unify pro HV mount with FC or 4in1 esc stack.
Placing it in the stack give it the cleanest of all the trial designs I thought up.

Notes: Best printed in ABS or high temp filament due to VTX temps

  1. There is a small front to rear offset. TBS fits in one direction only.
  2. Holes are 2.8mm in diameter. Run the screws back and forth while when threading.
  3. Tabs on the corners may need a small bet of trimming to have perfect fit, or can chop off (not really necessary, but added.
  4. The FC / 4in1 tower standoffs can be height adjusted easily in any cad program for individual needs->simple push/pull. This stl accounts for JST connectors on the bottom of my FC as well as the rubber grommets on my setup.
  5. Snug fit all around to keep the VTX from shifting around.

R-xsr / antenna mount almost finished, Will upload in apx 2days.

description.text:
My wife is always moaning about the IPads being left on the work top and making the place look untidy so I thought I would print a solution. I have also created another set for installation in a cupboard so when we are away they are safely hidden well out of sight. Next time I will print them in Wood PLA so they blend in a little more.

The IPad shelf mounts underneath a work top to store 1-3 IPads. You can even leave them on charge. As they are built in two parts these can be adjusted to hold a laptop, MacBook, iPad pro or any other tablet.

There is a back stop to ensure the iPads don't fall out and there are obviously fixing screw holes.

Printing wise; I would suggest 8% for infill. I first printed with 6% and whilst ok, seems a little weak. If you are using it for a laptop, maybe consider 10% I also printed at 0.3mm height as the finish is not crucial.

Note to users

The headphone jack opening is made at 6.5mm. To determine if this opening is sufficient for you, I advise looking at your headphone jack plug to see if the plug head is thinner than 6mm in diameter. Should the hole end up being a bit too small, one can consider drilling in small incremental steps of diameters to reach desired diameter.

With this design, the wireless charging port may not be accessible. If you charge via the mini USB port, this shouldn't matter much.

This case will fits snugly on the phone if you print in PLA, so take caution when you pry the case to fix your phone in.

title: Lens hood for Sony Tamron Minolta super wide agle zooms

description.text:
This lens hood is designed for an tight fit in mechanical and optical aspects. It is much smaller than the stock ones.

It is initially designed for the Minolta - AF 17-35 F2.8-4 D. It fits this lens perfectly in optical aspects. Since the design of the bayonet is common between the older Tamron designed super wides it will also fit several other lenses witch are also available with different mounts:

  • Tamron - SP AF 11-18 F4.5-5.6 Di II LD Aspherical IF
  • Minolta - AF DT 11-18 F4.5-5.6 D
  • Sony - AF DT 11-18 F4.5-5.6 D
  • Tamron - SP AF 17-35 F2.8-4 Di LD Aspherical IF
  • Minolta - AF 17-35 F2.8-4 D
  • Tamron - SP AF 10-24 F3.5-4.5 Di-II LD Aspherical IF

At the last one you will get shading at the borders of the frame. It should work with Canon, since the Canon apsc sensor is noticeable smaller then the ones of other competitors.

I hate most stock lens hoods, because they are way too bulky, the shape is rarely matched with the actual field of view and the fit often is so hard that they enforce the risk of damaging the internal mechanisms of the lens.

It has marks for alignment in working position. In reverse position an twist of about 45° will secure it.

title: Redcat Everest Gen7 Sport Inner Fenders remix

description.text:
Remix of Redcat's original Everest 7 inner fenders: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2584736
but more compatible with the the SPORT model (rather than the PRO):

REAR:When I printed and attached the original rear fenders, the 8 holes were bumped-out away from the frame. Fine for the Gen7 PRO model, but on the Gen7 SPORT the holes did not align properly, so I changed the holes to be flush with the frame, eliminating the gap between the 8 screw holes and the frame. There is also no roll cage on the SPORT model, so I removed the groove along the top of the fender for the roll cage pivot bar.

FRONT: cut-out a section at the front of the fender to prevent wheel-bite on the leading edge while turning or while shocks are fully compressed.

I redesigned both of these parts using Autodesk Meshmixer

author: RomanST

description.text:
This is an attempt to abuse my cheap Prusa i3 clone as a PCB-Drilling machine by temporarily attaching a Dremel next to the extruder.
The plan is to let the printer first drill the holes in exact positions and to spray the PCB with photoresist afterwards, to place the foil with the printout of the PCB in a precise manner by using the holes as marks.

I design my PCBs with gEDA/pcb and convert it's GCode-export to GCode suitable for 3D-printers with very basic perl-scripts I've written for this. You find them under the thing files.
You'll probably find your own way to generate GCode from your preferred PCB-design software. Please share your experiences!

I'm currently experimenting with best drilling-RPMs and vertical traveling speeds to make the drill no slip sideways before sinking into the material.

Please be aware, that using this thing may damage or even destroy your 3D-printer!
As you see, I have strengthened my printer here and there, so please be aware, that your printer may not be as robust as mine.

A non-informative video to show this in action can be found here: https://youtu.be/cp50UJrNE9w

UPDATE
I made this a customizable thing, but it does not work for some reason I'm still trying to find out. Please be patient or download OpenSCAD and make your own version at home.

comments.text:
I am going to try this with mine. I just got it and it is still in the box. Also was there separate software with your package
or did you have to down load it some place?
comments.author: GWGrant

comments.text:
This is not a complete solution, how you make it work depends on the tools you use.
I use pcb from the gEDA suite under Linux, because it is free software. I convert the drilling-G-code that it generates to G-code for my printer using the perl scripts you can find under thing files.
On my Windows-box I use Repetier Host to run the converted G-code on the printer.
There are self-explaining parameters an the beginning of the script to set distances, the home-position etc..

title: SMA spinner finger wrench for diversity receiver
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
There are many spinners available in this universe. But as you know: Too thick, surfaces I do not like, and many of them are not suitable to use with the diversity receivers due to a too big outer diameter. So, I have redrawn the orgin thing completely and resized the outer diameter to fit for Furious FPV True-D receivers also (smallest distance between SMA threads I know).

Most of the spinners I printed before need upscaling in order to make the hexagon big enough after shrinking of the material. Before you test and test again, please use SMA handle_110_108_106_104_102.stl (left to right) which includes versions of the spinner with the hexagon hole in mentioned percentage. After some tests I realised that the parts shrink different depending on the surface (never noticed this before). E.g. for ABS I need 104/106% when printed on the bed and 106/108% on a raft. Just print the 5in1 - afterwards you know which one you need and print the suitable separated one only.

description.text:
Spare parts for silicone gun of the brand KS Tools 980.1000 (find here: https://www.amazon.fr/KS-Tools-980-1000-Pistolet-Cartouches/dp/B001NYV13C). Stronger than original plastic parts.

  • Part 1.1 is a copy of the original part.
  • Part 1.2 has a smaller hole and is therefore stronger than part 1.1 (but not compatible with all refills).
  • Part 1.3, last made, was designed to go to the front of the gun (the notch allows the part to remain in place, replaces the original yellow tip).
  • Part 2 is a copy of the original but more solid part.

  • La pièce 1.2 a un trou plus petit et est donc plus solide que la 1.1 (mais pas compatible avec toutes les recharges).
  • La pièce 1.3, réalisée en dernier, a été conçu pour aller sur l'avant du pistolet (l'encoche permet à la pièce de ne pas bougée, remplace l'embout jaune d'origine).
  • La pièce 2 est une copie de la pièce d'origine mais plus solide.

title: Anycubic i3 Mega Ultrabase Bed Cable Support

description.text:
piercet's original guide looked the simplest way to get the bed cable sitting in a nice position due to my concerns about the heated bed cable breaking as others have had.

Due to the cable sitting inline with the Y-axis pully, the guide needs securing to keep it off centre. Hence the 3mm hole added for the thumb screw.

I removed the lower cover panel to cut the zip tie & pulled more heated bed cable up to the top. This allows the cable to move in a better direction, hopefully reducing the chance of the cable breaking at some point.

I used an old PC case thumb screw to secure the guide against the Y-axis frame. Make sure you line it up to miss the drive pulley for the Y-axis motor.

description.text:
I tried to print the holders from matrixFLYER, but they are not designed for use with t-nuts. The T-nut rested against the protrusion of the model and did not allow to completely pull the holder to the guide. I decided to measure the detail and completely draw it in the program. The lower part I left unchanged, as a guide. Higher it is not, so that the t-nut does not rest on the model. It turned out great!
Warning!
The model needs to be printed only from ABS plastic! LEDs 3050 are heated more than 80 degrees! This deforms the PLA plastic.
I'll try to figure out how to remove heat from the LEDs. Perhaps I will improve the model.

The like a proper design should be, USB jack is on the back of the Printrbot. I decided to do the same with the power plug so it was easier to connect. This also moved the PSU away from the printer for easier plugging and work on things.

To mount this I used the printed part as a template to cut out a hole in the back plate of the frame with a Dremel.
The female side of the plug can be salvaged from any old computer motherboards or be found at places like Digikey or surplus stores. The cable and male plug are actually from my original power supply because I removed the other cables and upgraded the gauge of wire going to my printer. This can be found at surplus stores or computer stores that sell parts for modular power supplies.
Once I soldered the male to female cable, the female plug was crazy glued onto the mount and then screwed onto the base with some of the remaining Printrbot screws and nuts.

"A mature neothelid is a gigantic worm scores of feet long and weighing tens of thousands of pounds". - d20srd.org

A Neolithid is the product of an Illithid reproductive cycle gone wrong. The tadpoles kept in the Elder Brain tank are constantly feeding on each other, to produce the strongest ones by the time they are ready to be implanted into another lifeforms brain. If one gets too big, the Illithids will see it as a potential threat and kill it. A Neolithid is one of those, but it grows too big for the Illithid caretakers to kill it in time. By the time they check on the tadpole pool, the Neolithid has most likely escaped the pool, being several feet long. From there, It grows bigger and bigger, and feeds on the brains of other creatures.

The base is a 4-inch "Gargantuan" size. The design is intended for D&D but you may use it for other RPGs.

description.text:
This is an attempt to create a Custom LCD Enclosure for 12.1" LCD Screen from a Laptop. It was designed to hold the LCD Control board with small speaker. No place was setup for speakers as there are many types out there.It is Also design to house a battery pack to power the board with a hole placed for a switch and power socket to charge the battery pack that you install without disassembly.The power socket is a standard 3.5mm type. and battery pack is a 12 volt 8000mha found at EBay or Amazon. I customized the battery pack for this project. The LCD Control board I designed for is a M.NT68676.2 which has HDMI, DVI, VGA, and audio in/out ports on it and runs about $25.00 on Ebay. LCD Screen is a LTN121A10 model from an old Chromebook and can be found on Ebay for as little as $15.00.
I included the button wall and the port walls so it could be custom to your board. Link to Project page:
https://www.tinkercad.com/#/?type=all&collection=projects&id=dmM4NFvqgNm

Sorry no pictures of semi finished project hence "Work in Progress" status.

I was asked to make a Hippo Cappuccino stencil for chocolate sprinkles.

This is surprisingly easy to do in Cura as you can import a JPEG image setting different thicknesses to darker and lighter colours.

To make your own custom stencil simply use the blank template above and add your own image into the circle in black and open the image in Cura with the following settings:

Height(mm) - 2.0
Base(mm) - 0.0
Width & Depth will be set by your image size
Use 'Lighter is higher' from the drop down box
Set the 'Smoothing' bar to minimum setting

I would live to see your results if you make your own design.

title: PanoBot Tripod Mount Generator
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a customizable thing which creates a tripod adapter plate which fits between tripod and Panobot central gear.
Panobot is an awesome Panorama and Gigapixel Roboter, which can be also found on thingiverse.

Instructions:

  • Open the thing in the customizer
  • Measure the dimensions of your tripod adapter plate (Have a look at the included sketch to know which dimensions to measure.)
  • Fill in the measured dimensions & Generate the Adapter
  • Print the Adapter starting from top to down (with the large disc laying on the print bed)
  • Enjoy the Panobot :)

Changelog

08/02/2018

  • released version 1.1.0 - added preset for known tripods (started with my Andoer); feel free to add yours by providing the measurements so that it can be added for others.

21/01/2018

  • released version 1.0.0 of customizable Panobot Mount generator

title: Reverse Bowden for Prusa i3
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Here's a reverse-Bowden setup for the Prusa I3 MK2/xx (haven't tested on a MK3, yet.)

It's called "reverse-Bowden" because the extruder doesn't push filament through a PTFE tube into the hot-end. Instead, it pulls the filament through the tube.

There are a few advantages (real or imagined) to using a reverse-Bowden setup for the Prusa i3. It allows you to take the heavy filament spool off the frame. It eliminates the need for a filament guide. Also, travel movements of the print head don't cause the filament to un-spool (a real problem with PETG.)

In my design, retraction is not affected. The PTFE tube sits, unattached, on top of the extruder and lifts up on retractions instead of having to push the filament back up the tube. (May not be a real problem, but it's one less thing to worry about.)

Note that I have, once again, taken Area51's clip design (see http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1940105) and used it in my own design. I have reverse-engineered it into OpenSCAD to make it easier to fit projects of mine that mount on the Prusa's frame. but the original design is his. This clip-mount makes for easy-on, easy-off and won't break off the ends when you attach or remove it (like I've done with the original Prusa spool holder "clip".)

If you're interested, you can find the design for the spool holder (pictured) here: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2618257 It works surprisingly well for the two sides not being connected. I just drop a spool on it, wiggle the spool and the two sides line right up.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

i3 MK2S

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.20

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Check your gcode - the thin strip on the clip should print with one perimeter (front and back) and a perimeter-sized line of infill. SImplify3d will, by default, print the single perimeters with no infill, resulting in a gap between perimeters that makes the flexible hinge more fragile. It will still work, but it won't be as strong. Use S3D's advanced features to change the way it does thin infill.

Because it's printed on its side, without supports, you may have to touch up the hole for the PTFE tube. I used a 5/32 drill bit (~4mm if available) (by hand) to gently ream out any irregularities. Note that there are some "nubs" in the bottom of the hole to grip the tube. Don't remove those. Also note that the hole coming out of the bottom of the tube hole is sized for filament. I cleaned mine with a 3/32" (~2mm) bit (again, by hand.) Check to be sure that the PTFE tube is not compressed so much as to interfere with the smooth movement of the filament.

I'm using a PTFE tube approximately 23" long - about 60cm. You want it long enough to allow an easy reach to the hot-end at it's extremes, but not too much longer. Mine, in the picture, could probably be a little shorter.

Use an M3x10 or M3x12 screw to attach the arm to the clip. There's a countersink for a socket-head screw. There's also a single layer printed as a support for the countersink. Just punch through it or clean it, as desired. Frankly, I don't use the screw, opting instead for some CA glue. There's probably no reason to disassemble it, so glue works well.
Designed in OpenScad.

title: Turn your Prusa i3 mk2s into a pen plotter (+ pen holder)

description.text:
This is a simple penholder for your Prusa i3 mk2s printer.
It will convert it into a fully functional Pen plotter without disassembling anything.

The Slic3r settings are given. (See the PenPloter_Slic3r_Config.ini and config_Bundle files)
Use it :

  • launch the gcode
  • when first beep, position the pen and the rubber band
  • 30s later a second beep tells that printing will start

That's it !

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3mklWhb0VZg

and details

https://youtu.be/acarCoNSVMY

final setting

add 4mm screw which will "auto tap" into the pre drilled holes on the pen holder
add 2 nuts+screw to fix the holder on the extruder stepper motor
add a rubber band, one end on the filament spring screw, the other on the pen holder
position the pen and put the cap so that the tip touches the paper when z = 13.5mm (or modify the parameters into the slicer program...)

convert image or svg to stl

use on line tools such as :
svg : http://svg2stl.com/
svg : http://3dp.rocks/lithophane/ (flat model, positive image)
bitmap : 2D image to STL : https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:66115

Now you have a stl file

Slic3r configuration and settings

see images into the "thing files".
You will need :

  • cut the stl to only keep one layer
  • set the PrintSettings with only 0.1mm layer, one single layer, no bottom/top layer, one perimeter
  • set the filament to cut all temperature (bed and extruder to 0°C)
  • set the Printer Settings into the Start G-Code section --> IMPORTANT TO DO IT
    and add these lines :

M115 U3.1.0 ; tell printer latest fw version

G28 W ; home all without mesh bed level
M104 S0 ; turn off temperature
M140 S0 ; turn off heatbed

G1 F600 Z+13.5 ; Raise the print nozzle out of the way
G1 X00 Y10 F1000.0 ;position the pen so that it touches the bed
M300 S1567 P240 ; Play a Beep
G4 P20000 ; pause for 30s
M300 S1567 P240 ; Play a Beep
M117 5s remaining ; One minute remaining warning
G4 P5000 ; pause 5s more
G1 Z13.2 ; goes down 0.3mm pen can write now
G92 Z0.2 ; Set absolute positioning for remaining print
G92 E0.0
G1 Z5 ; pen up before moving

In this example, the pen is positonned so that the tip touches the paper when Z is 13.5mm.
Move the top cover to achieve this
then this gcode goes down 0.3mm and fixes the first layer absolute position
When the printer will print it it will go to 0.1 (or 0.2) mm height, the pen will touch sligthly the paper and he ruber band will press it down gently.

Now another important parameter is to tell the printer to retract 2mm in Z for "pen up". This is done into the Extruder Setting tab.

author: alieneila

description.text:
I liked this model a lot, so I used Cyanhyena's high res model and scaled it up to 150%. I should have gone 200% but I can print it again. I cut it up and hollowed it out to reduce the material needed. The intent was to have a wall thickness of 2-3mm and therefore hollow. I welded the pieces together, coated in Smooth-Cast 321 and painted. The upper skull weighed in at about 750g and the jaw was about 400g.

  • It is not cut up into the largest pieces but cut up so that it would reduce supports. Supports at needed on most of the pieces but not all. I recommend brims on everything just for good measure.

  • The jaw was printed in one piece with 3 shells and 15% infill. A nub was removed to allow the jaw to be flexed just enough to fit onto the upper skull. At this scale the jaw is very rigid.

title: Vertex k8400 adjustable dual e3d v6 mount

description.text:
With this part you can add two e3d v6 hotends to your vertex k8400, and adjust the height of the second hotend. I used it for my printer since the two hotends I own (a genuine and a fake e3d v6) don't have the same height.
This might also work for a combination of a volcano and a v6, although I haven't tested that yet.

You need to add two normal m3 nuts, the rest of the nuts and bolts should be included in the spare parts of the vertex.

After printing, you can slide the parts together and install it. You can then adjust the second hotend's hieght and clamp it with the bolts.

description.text:
This is a fan duct that allows you to mount 120mm radiators in your computer case at an angle.
I made this as a way to make my computer look more modern as many of the new cases shown at CES this year had the ability to mount radiators and fans in a similar location within the case.

Printer:

Geeetech i3 MK2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

15%

Assembly:

Everything just need to be glued together.

  • Glue the "lid" part to the "chamber" part and wait for it to dry.
  • Glue the "face" part to the first part using a screw in the screw hole of the design to allign the parts.

(Be sure to glue so that every where the parts touches there is a proper seal.)

Box for the CR10, I tried to make it beautiful ! let me know your thoughts about it.

I'll be happy to get some feedback !

title: Prusa MK3 Spool Holder for 30mm Spools
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Upon attempting to print with Sainsmart TPU on my new MK3 I discovered the spool doesn't fit on the included spool holder. Since I just finished modeling a spool holder for the same reason on my CR-10 I decided to create a mount for it for the MK3. It's based on the factory spool holder but modeled from scratch in Fusion 360. If the fit is tight shave some material off the three ribs on the inside surface of the mount.

Fits filament spools with at least a 30mm through hole and maximum 95mm width.

title: Beefier hull for "Space Troops Armed Tank"

description.text:
I've modified the hull on Typhus94's excellent tank a little bit.
Beefed it up in a few places, both for visual effect and to make it print better on my Flashforge finder.
The turret sits a little taller on this hull, i had problems spinning the turret on the original design.
I gave it a different rear so it looked less like an transport.

  • I made it fit better with the sponsoned tracks. Not sure it works with Typhus94's transport trackunits anymore.

motionEyeOS is a Linux distribution that turns your single board computer into a video surveillance system. Check out the wiki for more details.

If you have a spare Raspberry Pi - or any of a number of other single board computers - you can use motionEyeOS to keep an eye on your 3D printers.

I have been using motionEyeOS for a couple of years in a homebrew security system involving three Raspberry Pi’s and six cameras. It just seemed logical to use what I know to watch my 3D printers.

I’m not the author of motionEyeOS, but I have his permission to spread the word about his project. And it’s free!

Wiki (all about motionEyeOS): https://github.com/ccrisan/motioneyeos/wiki

Supported devices: https://github.com/ccrisan/motioneyeos/wiki/Supported-Devices

Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/motioneyeos/

I’ve included a 3D model of the motionEyeOS logo.

title: GoPro Hero 4 Black adapter for X-Cam Sight 2 gimbal

description.text:
This is a GoPro Hero 4 Black edition camera adapter modified for mounting onto the X-Cam Sight 2 gimbal. It may also work with other phone holders as well.

The weight of the camera and the adapter is too light for the gimbal. I added two M6 screws with self locking nuts to provide extra 20 grams of weight so that the gimbal works properly.

description.text:
This is a remix of the wonderful case design for the Protoneer Raspberry Pi CNC Hat by janbvik.

I use this to control a small 3018 Chinese router so the stepper drivers are installed in the unit. I raised the top a little to make room for the heat sinks and installed a spot for a 60mm fan to cool the stepper drivers.

I also extended the top so that you can print it only needing supports for the corner mounting holes. It prints much cleaner this way. I made no changes to the bottom but include it here for completeness.

I used M2 heatsets for the body and M3 heatsets for the fan mounts.

title: Socket Box for Xiaomi Aquara switch

description.text:
Standard european round socket boxes are too small to fit Xiaomi Aquara switch. It is possible to order special 'chineese size' 86mm boxes on ebay, but they require too big hole and hard to mount accurately into existing interior.

So I designed something in between - big enough to fit Xiaomi Aquara switch, but not as big as 86mm boxes so that I can hide the box underneath the switch. It was possible to keep wallpapers outside the box untouched.

Basically ABS is not the best material for power boxes, but more or less ok considering the switch and relay inside has their own case. Nylon will probably ok as well, while PLA is not good for this thing (too low melting temperature)

Note: I slightly improved the model comparing with shown on pictures. Particularly when mounting I realized that breakable holes should be closer to box bottom.

description.text:
My wife's beautiful long hair seems to clog her sink and our standing shower drain pretty frequently. You can remove the sink trap and clean it no problem, but what do you do about the shower? I bought a cover to go over the drain cap, but the hair was able to go around it and still clog the shower. So I decided to design a new screen with smaller holes and print it in a waterproof material. This should work on most standard 4" drains. I calculated the area of holes that the water could travel through in the original drain cap and tried to match the areas with a larger amount of smaller 3 mm holes.

The jury is still out on the effectiveness, but as a mechanical engineer I believe this should work out if we can manage to keep it clean.

I had a jam on the last layer, so the top didn't print complete smoothly, but I will print it again and update the photo.

Designed 100% in Shapr 3D on the iPad

Having used AutoCAD since 1990, I can say without hesitation that for 3D designs like this Shapr 3D is super intuitive and easy to use once you get used to the design metaphor. I have start designing everything from vintage car parts to drones to things around the house in this software. I am not affiliated with them in any way, I just think they have created a killer iPad app that you can work on anywhere (I travel for work used it on the plane or in front of the TV on the weekend).

Here's a link to their website if you are interested.
https://shapr3d.com

L.Y. Beeker, Adam M. Pringle, Joshua M. Pearce. Open-source parametric 3-D printed slot die system for thin film semiconductor processing. Additive Manufacturing 20 (2018) 90–100. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.addma.2017.12.004 open access https://www.academia.edu/35667969/Open-sourceParametric3-DPrintedSlotDieSystemforThinFilmSemiconductor_Processing

Franklin firmware: http://www.appropedia.org/Franklin
OpenSCAD: http://www.openscad.org/
Open-source syringe pump: http://www.appropedia.org/Open-sourcesyringepump
Prusa conversion - follow same procedure as Open-source Wax RepRap 3-D Printer for Rapid Prototyping Paper-Based Microfluidics: http://www.appropedia.org/Open-sourceWaxRepRap3-DPrinterforRapidPrototypingPaper-Based_Microfluidics

with the new x carriage provided in this paper. https://osf.io/m2zqk/

Slot die coating is growing in popularity because it is a low operational cost and easily scaled processing technique for depositing thin and uniform films rapidly, while minimizing material waste. The complex inner geometry of conventional slot dies require expensive machining that limits accessibility and experimentation. In order to overcome these issues this study follows an open hardware approach, which uses an open source 3-D printer to both fabricate the slot die and then to functionalize a 3-D slot die printing system. Polymer materials are tested and selected for compatibility with common solvents and used to fabricate a custom slot die head. This slot die is then integrated into a 3-D printer augmented with a syringe pump to form an additive manufacturing platform for thin film semiconductor devices. The full design of the slot die system is disclosed here using an open source license including software and operational protocols. This study demonstrates that functional lab-grade slot dies may be 3-D printed using low-cost open source hardware methods A case study using NiO2 found an RMS value 0.486 nm, thickness of 17–49 nm, and a maximum optical transmission of 99.1%, which shows this additive manufacturing approach to slot die depositions as well of fabrication is capable of producing viable layers of advanced electronic materials. Using this method, a cost savings of over 17,000% was obtained when compared to commercial slot die systems for laboratories.
Materials and methods

See http://www.appropedia.org/Open-source_parametric_3-D_printed_slot_die_system_for_thin_film_semiconductor_processing

title: Yet Another OpenSCAD Rounded Cube Library

description.text:
While working on a model of a toy truck, I needed a module to make cubes with arbitrary edges rounded. Looking around, I couldn't find anything that quite did what I was looking for. Sembiance's OpenSCAD Rounded Cube Corners came closest, but I don't like the intersection of three cylinders look when three rounded edges come together.

I'd been playing around some with hulls around corner spheres already and when looking for inspiration, came across agodinhost's OpenSCAD Rounded Cube doing just that.

Combining the two ideas together, this library uses cubes, cylinders, and spheres to define the corners based on which edges should be rounded, then draws a hull around the whole thing to make the cube. This makes for very nice looking corners and edges for every arrangement I can think of.

Calculating hulls around curved primitives isn't the fastest operation, so I generally do my drafting with $fn around 30 or lower, then crank it up to 100 or so for STL renders.

author: cilynx

description.text: To fill up the outer edges of your aftermarket stereo in a Audi TT 8n (Mk1) If correctly printed, they have a snug fit, and will nof fall out :)

4-way coupler for connecting PVC pipe. This one is designed for a slip fit over 3/4 inch schedule 40 PVC pipe, but its parametric so it can be adjusted to join any size pipe. Though you can't see it in the preview, there's a little ledge inside that will stop the pipes from sliding through or colliding inside the coupler. Its chopped in half for easy printing. I've also added some pads to help the part stick to a cold platform, and counteract the tenancy for warping which makes gluing them together more difficult.

• If you'll need something other that a 3/4" Schedule 40 PVC slip fit coupling, edit the OpenSCAD file and modify the variables as desired. Grab the software from openscad.org if you don't have it. The variables to edit are at the top in the first few lines.
    • pipe_od = the outer diameter of the pipe to fit in the coupler, in millimeters (26.67)
    • gap = the clearance between the pipe outer diameter and coupler inner diameter (1.0)
    • ledge = size of the ledge that stops the pipe from sliding through (2.0)
    • wall = wall thickness of the coupler (3.0)
    • pad_w = wall thickness of the anti-warping pads
    • pad_r = radius of the anti-warping pads
  • Save and compile the OpenSCAD file, and generate an STL file.
  • Print two of them. I used Cura 12.07 default settings, PLA, with 50% infill. 190 degrees. Each half is about 1.5 hours to print.
  • Clean out the strings if necessary. Use a hobby knife to trip off the anti-warping pads.
  • Glue them together with cyanoacrylate. If they are a bit warped and don't fit perfectly, heat up the flat faces. I put them in a hot pan until they're just hot enough that they aren't quite sticky, then press them together, and wick the glue into the seams. This technique needs some improvement. Or a heated print bed to eliminate warping in the first place.
  • Use.

This is a case for "Momoinololu" control board and is intended to be used in atom 3D printer (Genkei) mainly. June-2, 2014
Some minor change on case top for 60sq. DC fan.
April-24, 2014
Added case top and fan-guard parts for 60 sq. fan using. Following screws and nuts might used.
For 60sq fan,
M3 x 35mm x 4 For 50sq. fan,
M3 x 35mm x 2 (for case)
M3 x 30mm x 2 (for DC fan) "momoinololu_case_snap_on.123dx" is only idea sketch that makes easy accessing and building. Please see detail at http://kogecha01.blog.fc2.com/

Requires 200mm wide bed and sufficient support under the arms.

The idea here is that 1. it spins around easily, 2. it's small enough for a cat to pick up.
My cats aren't actually using it yet, so I'm leaving it "in progress" in case I make some improvements later.

title: Filament Guide for top mount LCD spool holder
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I made this thing to go with the top mounted spool holder I use. That bracket on it just takes out some of the wobble in that spool holder. See https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2320150 for what I'm talking about.

I wanted a filament guide to go with that setup, but didn't really see one I liked so I whipped this up using 3D Builder (Windows 10 freebie) based on other items I saw in my search. I wanted something wider, so it would (I assume) be more stable and less prone to just falling off or something.

Three versions: one is 6cm wide, one is 5.2cm wide (which I'm using), and the last is 4.5cm wide. If you're using the spool holder bracket like I am, then print either the 5.2cm or 4.5cm so it'll fit along with the bracket. I found the 5.2cm one just fits, so I made a slightly shorter one that'll fit with space to spare. Your choice as to which you use.

I've also added 3 versions in the same lengths with a rounded front bumper or runner on them. After using the 5.2cm version, I noted that with some filaments the extruder movements would end up dragging the filament across the LCD and acrylic which I didn't like. The rounded bumper should help he filament to turn away from the LCD and acrylic frame member of the machine, so it no longer rubs against them. This was happening with spools that were mostly spent, and we know how the filament near the end of the spool likes to twist and bend on it's own as it unwinds.

Printer:

ANET A8

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.24

Infill:

15%

Notes:

I printed this at .24, 2 shells and 10% infill, and realized it would look slightly better at .2 and 15-20%. It just fits over the top acrylic holding the LCD on my A8.

Just used 3D Builder since all I needed was simple thing. I don't like using a program with excessive bells and whistles to make something so simple if I don't have to since it just complicates things unless you are really familiar with that program and use it a lot.

title: Monoprice Select Mini Z Carriage
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I purchased a V2 mini off of ebay as a parts printer and after a few repairs it's as good as new, however the x-axis end stop switch post was broken on the original carriage. I also found out the mount for the lead screw was integrated into the carriage design so you can't add a nema 17 motor without replacing the carriage. This helped in both areas for me.

I'm not the original designer, just modified it for my preferences. I integrated an end stop switch bracket, cut down the one side to accept the standard 35mm bearings (length), enlarged the bearing holes and thickened the mounting plates for the nema 17 motor and the lead screw nut. The original was two piece design and I made it into a one piece design.

Original design:

https://www.myminifactory.com/object/replacement-z-axis-assembly-for-monoprice-select-mini-v1-52822

I used petg with 100% infill for structural integrity.

It printed the outer and inner shell and it's gap fill make a thicker bead in the middle for a solid wall.  Other software or printers may need to play with tweaking the settings some so that you get a single solid wall instead of 2 detached shells.

remixed_from.author: kresty
remixed_from.title: On Air Sign (Desk or Horizontal Mount)

remixed_from.author: kresty
remixed_from.title: Stupid Segoe UI Black Font with Oversized "holes" for placing them.

description.text:
(See my "On Air" sign for an example of one lit up)

This sign is intended to be lit up to warn others that a room is "In Use" or occupied. Such as for outside a darkroom door.

We haven't figured out the electronics yet. Planning to use something like a WS2812b LED with a wifi microcontroller. "Hey Cortana, I'm recording now!" (or something like that).

Temporarily, we stuck a couple christmas tree lights inside, connected to a wall switch inside the room.

There are 2 and 3 sided wall-mountable versions and a 2 sided desk mount version. Each has variants with and without integral letters, so you can either print letters in another color or paint them. The 3 sided version also comes in a 2-part one with a removable top to avoid the support marks showing through the translucent filament.

Included is a wall mount intended for the wall signs to hang from.

Full disclosure: Gearbest gave me the CR-10 that I printed this with, so I feel sort of obligated to put it through it's paces.

If you like my things, I don't mind Tips, but checking out our Lego R2-D2 YouTube page also helps!

Printer:

Creality CR-10

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2mm

Notes:

Obviously print the sign in translucent filament. We used ABS. You can scale the whole thing up or down some if desired.

Printing the letters in something like black and gluing them on later is probably better than painting, but there's a 1-piece version if you want to paint it.

The 3 sided version also comes in a two-part varient. That's good because then you can print the parts and avoid the lines left by the supports.

No support is needed, except for the single section 3 sided version. I used 5% for that.

The letters probably don't need infill either, but I'd use 10% or so for the wall mount.

Simplify 3D's gap fill did a great job with the thin walls, 3 upper and lower layers and 2 shells. It printed the outer and inner shell and it's gap fill make a thicker bead in the middle for a solid wall. Other software or printers may need to play with tweaking the settings some so that you get a single solid wall instead of 2 detached shells.

Painting Letters

If you choose to print the one-piece version with the painted letters, then you'll probably need to make sure to use paint. Markers don't work on filament because they wick into the gaps and a terrible smudge oozes out from the letters.

I knew that and still tried a marker with horrid results. (fortunately some alcohol cleaned it off).

Gluing Letters

Be careful with the letter orientation. In particular, the "O" isn't symmetrical. So make sure they look right before gluing.

Obviously the glue/solvent depends on the material you print with. We printed in ABS, so used MEK (not recommended because it's nasty).

Note that the solvent makes it easy to smear the black letters onto the translucent sign, so be careful not to smudge them.

Gluing the Two-Part Top

If you print the two-part 3 sided sign, use care gluing the top on. Any solvent that glues the parts together is also likely to smudge or streak the clear parts if it drips down the sides.

We had luck putting a thin layer of solvent along the top edge and then pressing the top onto that. A bit didn't get sealed though, so we had to try some more and caused a dreaded drip.

Wall Mount

One part is a wall (or desk?) mount to secure the sign. It's intended to be affixed to the wall with two screws, and then the sign hangs from that. Since it depends a bit on gravity, it probably won't be great on a desk (I'm working on that.)

I used Sketchup

The file's included. I build the base for the sign, then stamped out some letters. The biggest trick was making the recessed hole for the letters. It has to be a little bigger than the letters, so that was a bit of painful hand-editing to make the recessed bits 0.5mm bigger on all sides.

In the future I think I'll try the Fredo6 Round Corner extension. I think that by "embossing" the letters on the flat surface, then I can "round" the corners of that surface (like with only 1 side to round it), and then chop off the rest of it. Then extrude the resulting letter, which should be slightly bigger than the original.

print_settings.Notes:: Recommended that you print it in the same orientation it imports in.

description.text: I liked the design of Fuganater's CR-10 Center GoPro Mount and I wanted to use it on my Tevo Tornado. I used this mount for my Logitech c920 webcam. Works great!

Printer:

Tevo Tornado

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Like Fuganater suggests, print with more wall/plane layers. I used 4 layers on all walls/planes and 20% infill. Fuganater suggests 3 layers and %15, but I like to be on the safe side, even with the extra weight.

Recommended that you print it in the same orientation it imports in.

Fixup

I made the holes 0.2mm wider than the parts, which should give a snug fit if your printer is accurate. It is quite possible for there to be extra material or slumped plastic that you'll need to cut/file away. If you printed with 4 layers, you won't have any worries about compromising the hole's strength.

What I changed

Widened the screw and print bed leveling spring holes to fit the Tevo Tornado M5 screws and 10mm springs.

title: S3 Ninja Star 2018 - indoor FPV racing drone - tiny whoop

description.text:
The S3 Ninja Star 2018 is a more durable, lightweight, 3D-printable frame alternative for the Blade Inductrix, Tiny Whoop or similar nano-sized FPV drone. No hardware required!

YouTube build guide video here
Google Docs build guide here
Purchase a kit with everything you need to build and fly this here

This 2018 version embodies several improvements over the original S3 Ninja Star frame, including:

  • new integrated battery holder
  • new snap-fit camera mount
  • new full propeller guard protection
  • new snap-off tabs to indicate front of frame, motor spin direction
  • redesigned motor mounts for easier press-fit
  • redesigned aerodynamic frame with guard and no-guard versions
  • improved flight control board snap-fit
  • eliminated need for rubber bands

The frame and its components are designed to fit any of the following brushed flight control boards:

  • Beecore (F3 Evo, with bind button preferred)
  • BeeBrain
  • BetaFPV
  • stock Blade Inductrix
  • other similarly sized brushless boards

While assembling (instructions and video coming soon):

  • use the arrow tabs to orient your frame, flight controller, motors and props first
  • carefully bend and snap-off the arrow tabs
  • over the posts, lay the battery holder, snap-in your flight controller, then snap-in the camera mount

Printed with ArianePlast PLA metallic black.

Model is probably scaled down by 10, so just move the period and scale is fine.

This is an Eppendorf-Tube centrifuge with a spherical hinge cover and freely rotatable tubesockets.
Alternatively i designed a static tubeholder rotor that creates a lot less airdrag and should make higher speeds possible.

The motorsocket is now 26 x 29 mm in width and 42 mm in hight. ( differs from the picture )
The rotor is mounted directly onto the motor and has a stability support in the spherical cover and also on top of the motor socket, it also can be further stabilized with a screw through the cover into the rotor.
The motorsocket has now holes to apply cooling to the motor.

There are also 4 holes to screw rubberfeet onto the bottom of the main body

I printed the main body with 10 % infill and the rotor at 100% infill.

If you would print all with 100% infill it would weight about 1.2kg.

Be aware of the dangers of centrifuge accidents.

Feel free to leave your thoughts and if you print it post your prints and tell me how its running for you, it would seriously interest me.
The noise at first in the video is coz of the motor which i havent had glued into its socket when i recorded this.

print_settings.Notes:: I do have a concern about snapping the motor mount which is why I added the taller vertical angle. I think the pancaking of the stepper will add enough support to prevent this but don't go bashing this into anything ;)

title: titan mount for c-bot / d-bot multi-purpose x carriage

description.text:
This is a simple titan mount for my extruder plate

You will need a few different parts for this to work:

  1. 7 x m3 10mm low profile ( 8 would work too )
    • Note, there is a very small gap between the titan large gear and the top of the screw - may grind the gear
  2. 3 x m3 35mm
  3. original m3 25mm screw from the titan

6 of the m3 10s are to mount the plate. The 7th replaces the m3 6mm behind the groove mount.

I have not yet printed with this mount so please report back if you run with it. I'll be modifying my c-bot to use this new setup when I get some time. I have another change or two to prep before making the switch myself.

I originally wanted this to support a dual extruder setup. The spacing of the titan, especially with the aero I have, this is just not going to be an easy / stable thing for now. I want to at least get a single extruder going on this thing.

I'm including the fusion360 design in case anyone wants to remix/modify it. Pretty simple part

Printer:

c-bot

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

same as the other parts I've been using - 3.25 perimeters and 20% infill seem to produce a nice rigid part.

I do have a concern about snapping the motor mount which is why I added the taller vertical angle. I think the pancaking of the stepper will add enough support to prevent this but don't go bashing this into anything ;)

author: donandi

description.text:
This is a stackable dispenser box that will hold 1 meter of heatshrink. In the photo I have printed boxes and filled them with 1.5, 2.5, 3.5 and 5.0mm heatshrink. 5.0mm is the largest diameter the hole in the lid can accommodate. This dispenser box can be used for other items such as solder, thread, cord, etc,.

Please note that in the attached STL files I have made the joint the full height of the box, which makes for a more stiffly joined box to its neighbour. The photo shows the first incarnation of this model with a very short 10mm joiner.

The lid is a very tight compression fit.

Please print one box and lid and assess suitability for your application before printing multiples copies. The lid may be too tight if you intend to remove and refit the lid very often, but I wanted a lid that would be very secure. It can be sanded slightly if you want a less close fitting lid.

title: Raspberry Pi Wireless Time-Lapse Camera (Easy Print)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
An easy to print raspberry pi wireless camera holder with recessed LED holes for 5mm white LEDs. I would highly recommend "diffusing" the LEDs by sanding them with 400 grit sandpaper before installation. Fits perfectly on a COTS gooseneck holder.

Before the details, how about a timelapse of one of these cameras being printed:

https://twitter.com/brendonbuilds/status/955457300524920832

Now, on to the build!

Parts:
Raspberry Pi Wireless
Raspberry Pi Camera

Gooseneck with clamp: http://amzn.to/2EYHpgw

8 - 5mm white LEDs
8 - 100 ohm resistors
8 - #2 0.25" screws
4 - #2 0.5" screws
4 - #2 0.75" screws
1 - M4 12mm bolt/nut
400 grit sandpaper (optional, but recommended)

Installation:

Mount the official raspberry pi camera to the front with #2 0.25" screws then install the LEDs/wiring. I'd recommend using a 3d pen to secure the LEDs in place. Mount the raspberry pi wireless module to the back with #2 0.25" screws. After testing all the wiring/connections (important!) join the front and back pieces with the #2 0.75" screws.

Place the M4 nut into the recess in the back anchor. I'd recommend using a 3d pen to secure the nut in place. Use the #2 0.5" screws to join the back anchor to the back of the camera assembly. Use the M4 bolt to create a rotating joint between the bracket and the back anchor.

Connect the bracket to the threaded end of the gooseneck. This connection is purposefully very tight and will cause the threads to really dig into the plastic.

Software:

I use the motion service as a webcam server to line up the shots before starting a timelapse. Here's a great writeup for setting up the webcam:

https://pimylifeup.com/raspberry-pi-webcam-server/

I use raspistill to capture the timelapse images:

https://www.raspberrypi.org/documentation/usage/camera/raspicam/timelapse.md

I then use avidemux to convert from .avi to .mp4 (mp4v2) (use hardware h264 for speed and twitter compatibility):

https://sourceforge.net/projects/avidemux

Printer Brand:

Robo 3D

Printer:

R1 ABS + PLA Model

No

Supports:

No

author: brendonbuilds

description.text: Recreio home

Tips for printing: Use a large nozzle and larger layer heights to save time.
No infill necessary (unless you want to)

There are in-built holes at the back of the model, designed for small nails (pictured) so you can attach it to the wall. The nail head should be no longer than 4mm in diameter.

My printer failed towards the end because I had a snag in the filament (no fault of the model or the printer!), so in the photograph of the one I've printed, the ends facing you are open - the model is actually designed to have rounded-off, closed edges. If you manage to print one all the way to completion please upload I would love to see it! :-)

Thanks for looking!

title: Pillars for Märklin bridges
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
From the 1950s until 1970 Märklin offered a series of bridges made of tin. For the bridges the pillars 7064 (30mm) and 7065 (30mm) were offered.
Unfortunately many of the old pillars from the 1950s and 1960s are so distorted and deformed today that they became unusable.
I redesigned the pillars in 6mm and 30mm and also in 60mm a size Märklin never has offered.

A version for double-bridges can be found at: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2783344

A Simple 3D printed case for a WEMOS D1 Mini WiFi microprocessor board.

The design of this board is slightly different from the ones with the beveled corners. However, this case should fit the board with beveled corners as well.

The cover is a push fit and has slots on the longer edges that make the PINS and their labels visible.

You can fit the WEMOS board with or without the PIN rails soldered to the board. However, the case may have to be mounted on one of the sides.

One side of the case has a small opening to access the RESET pin.
